story:
The beginning

Fotopia Collective was born in Cluj-Napoca, Romania, from the common desire of uniting forces to promote photojournalism and documentary photography.

IN/OUT Transylvania Photo Festival aims to engage a large audience with documentary photography, and talk about the importance of visual storytelling. We want people to see the work of photographers, not only on a telephone or computer screen but as printed photographs, large displays or screenings. While other festivals in Romania focus on photography in general we want to educate, promote and celebrate documentary photography and photojournalism.

This year at In/Out we will look at the way Romania is represented through visual stories made by both local and foreign photographers, and discuss about how documentary photography sometimes taps in the existing stereotypes about Romania. How are we seen from the outside? How are we seen from the inside?

These are some of the artists that we invited to exhibit between 10.27 and 11.06 in Cluj Napoca, Romania: Andrei Nacu, Bogdan Gîrbovan, Cosmin Bumbuţ, Ioana Cîrlig, Laura Pannack, Marin Raica, Marko Risović, Petruţ Călinescu, Tomas Bachot.

This is just the beginning and we hope to grow together over the next years. From our experience, we know these goals are not impossible with a little bit of help.

 

What We Need & What You Get

You will help to start something that we believe in, something that on the long run will help everyone with an eye for photography.

We need 10,000 USD, which will cover half of the costs of the festival. The money will go for prints, frames and other materials needed for exhibitions. We will host a series of events that range from presentations and debates to screenings and workshops. We want to provide transportation and accommodation to artists but also a couple of surprises for the public.

Everyone will be included in our benefactors list that will be published on the festival’s website and Facebook Page.

 

How we got here

Our first project was a photo gathering at Banfy Castle in Bontida, near Cluj where photographers from all over Romania came to present their work and talk about the current situation of the industry in our country. We discussed the idea of having a documentary festival in Cluj and everyone agreed we need such an event to bring photojournalist, documentary photographers and a large audience together.

To prepare for the festival and to make people aware of what we do, we organized Playground Stories, a one week documentary photography workshop where we worked with students in Cluj. The stories they shot were exhibited at the neighborhood’s playground. Inspired by Missouri Photo Workshop, we plan on mapping the city through stories by taking the workshop to every neighborhood.

We were happy to witness the variety of reactions people have while looking at photographs from their own backyard. On top of that, it’s encouraging to see an outdoor exhibit, untainted and placed on a playground, survived more than a week without a scratch, graffiti or any other kind of damage.

 

Risks & Challenges

So far, running on enthusiasm paid off. We are not afraid to tackle this project because we know how much the photographic community, especially photojournalists in particular will benefit from this venture.

We plan for the worst and hope for the best. If we don’t get all the funding we will work with what we’ll have, considering a smaller number of events or smaller prints. We are a young collective and we are just starting, but we hope the festival will grow over the years.

 

Other Ways You Can Help

In/Out Transylvania Photo Festival will create an opportunity for people in Cluj and Romania to rediscover their country through unbiased projects of well established or emerging photographers. You can make this happen with a little bit of financial help but also by spreading the word. Give a shout to your friends, invite them to consider our project and don’t forget to follow, like and share.

All the “tools” you need ar at the top of the page.

 

The Team

Andreea Câmpean - Exhibitions & Screenings Manager

Andreea has an MA in Visual Anthropology from Free University in Berlin. Her work has appeared in The New York Times, Wall Street Journal, The Washington Post, Time, Le Monde, Paris Match, The Guardian, and Newsweek. She frequently contributed to Reuters, AFP and the United Nations. Her work often focuses on documenting issues related to displacement and the effects of conflict. She has covered the ramifications of war in South Sudan and Central African Republic, and migration in Spain, Greece, Morocco. She also covers arts, fashion and sports culture in marginalised countries or communities.

 

Călin Ilea - Festival Manager

Călin Ilea is a freelance photographer based in Cluj Napoca, Romania. Călin has worked with several Romanian newspapers and magazines such as Pro Sport, Evenimentul Zilei, Capital, Unica but also photo news agencies like Mediafax Foto. Călin holds a BA degree in journalism from Babes Bolya Unversity in Cluj-Napoca, Romania and MA degree in Photojournalism with a Fulbright scholarship at the University of Missouri School of Journalism in Columbia, Missouri.

 

Roxi Pop - Programme director

Roxi Pop graduated with a Fulbright scholarship the MA Journalism program of the University of Missouri. In 2012, after finishing the bachelor's program in Journalism from the Babes Bolyai University in Cluj, she went to the United States to develop her visual storytelling skills,  and explore a culture very different from her own.  Attracted by communities with a unique character, for her MA project she spent two summers documenting Chautauqua gated community from upstate New York. After finishing master, she moved to Norfolk, Virginia and worked for  Matt Eich, a world wide know documentary photographer. After the internship with Eich, Roxi spent another summer in Chautauqua, teaching  photography workshops and putting in place her personal show, “Chautauqua Dreamworld.” After 3 years in the U.S., Roxi returned to  Romania,  and started her personal project "Today I am Home". 

 

Vakarcs Loránd - Production Manager

Vakarcs Loránd, artist and photojournalist, graduated “Ion Andreescu’’ Visual Arts Academy in 2005. He worked with local and national newspapers and agencies such as, Clujeanul, Adevărul, Gazeta Sporturilor and since 2014 he is a photographer for the Romanian magazine Sinteza. Lorand defines himself as fine art documentary photographer and since 2010 follows the change and downfall of an industry inherited from the communist period but also the landscapes and people from isolated Romanian villages. Panoramic images are a part of the interpretation and personal vision of the documentation subject.

story:
Short Summary

The CHEWED production is underway. We had an extremely successful shoot on August 20th and 21st. Very hot, very hectic, time was always running out, but we got it done. I am incredibly lucky to have such an amazing team behind this project.

We now have Casey Parsons slated to do our illustrating, and he's presently working on a comic project called Blood Moon. https://www.facebook.com/caseyparsonsart/

FX artist Scott Patterson did some GREAT work on the first shoot, and he's of course an integral part of the next outdoor shoot as well.

Toulouse Le Chat's scenes are all shot! (he plays "Ezekiel" in Chewed)

We were also so lucky to have pro stunt coordinator Ken Quinn on board as a stunt consultant. Things could have gotten ugly without him!

The cast of Chewed on set (from left, Chris Cracknell, Francesco De Francesco, Monika Meyer, Timothy Hevesi, John Migliore, and our Director of Photography Tim Dashwood:

 

What We Need & What You Get

This campaign is, of course, a continuation of the first one. Many people were disappointed they didn't get to contribute, and this is their chance to fix that! :) 

I'm going to have paintings as perks again, along with guitar lessons (that's new). The other perks, posters, soundtracks, supporter credits, etc. will be back as well.

 

The Impact

When I heard legendary director, George A. Romero speak at a recent convention he lamented the fact that horror movies don't have any deeper meaning these days. Chewed addresses that problem, and delivers with a sense of humour and guts (literal and figurative).

 

 

Risks & Challenges

We are almost done shooting! We have one more day to go, mostly outdoors, and we're going to gather the crew together again, borrow a Jeep, and race (carefully) up and down a narrow trail in the "jungles" of Hamilton. It is exciting to make a movie, but expensive (even a short), and this is the lowest of the low budget scale. I'm just barely squeaking by, while directing, editing, composing the score, and producing myself. 

 

 

Other Ways You Can Help

As always, if you can't contribute, please use the "share" tools on this page. THANK YOU!

story:
Also view the 9/23/16 development update video here from Twitch!

 

 

Hero's Song is a hardcore action RPG and uses the familiar click-to-move and attack controls of classic action RPGs like Diablo III or Path of Exile. Combat takes a more measured pace, giving you time to react to the intelligent tactics of your enemies and to thoughtfully deploy your wide variety of skills and abilities. True to its hardcore nature, combat in Hero's Song is dangerous and has very real consequences including the chance of permanent death. Friendly fire is always defaulted to "on", so positioning and precision are very important considerations. Death will come quickly if you think this is a simple clickfest.

 

In Hero's Song players can control their own server and host thousands of other players (with up to hundreds playing at one time.)

  • Join an existing community or host your own server
  • Create and control your worlds and make each server truly unique
  • Decide who gets to play on your server
  • It's your choice to disallow friendly fire and PvP
  

 

"Ever was the Lonely God in The Kalos"

 

 

The heart and soul of Hero's Song is in our world creation. In fact, the mythos we're making is so important to the game that we partnered with New York Times Bestselling author Patrick Rothfuss to help us make it awesome. He's been working with us to create this amazing backstory.

The backstory to Hero’s Song changes each time you create a new world, but it still has elements of the backstory we created woven into it.

Each god is unique and has specific interests which influence the physical geography of the world, who lives there, and how its history plays out. For example if you choose Nae, Goddess of the Sea as one of your elder gods, you'll end up with a lot more oceans; if you choose Cor, The Mad Smith, you should expect to see a lot more mountains. But the influence of the gods only begins with the geography of your world. Those same gods also impact the next phase of world creation - our deep world history.

  

 

The gods you choose to bind to your world influences far more than its physical geography. The gods also shape its entire population and thousands of years of history including the wars that were fought, the great plagues that ravaged the land, and the rise and fall of entire civilizations. On one world, Dranuk Dwarves may have never existed; on another, the Varloosh have fought a never-ending war with the Analathi Elves.  

The possibilities are near endless and ever expanding. This unique world history runs deep into the very bloodlines of the heroes you play, with family traits passed down through the ages and the treasures of your heritage waiting to be discovered.

  

 

From an ever-expanding cosmology, you determine the pantheon for each world; choosing the gods of creation and the balance of divine power. These choices shape the world, its vast history, and the nature of its afterlife.

These are just a few of the gods that are available and more will be added over time, both by the Pixelmage team and by the players themselves as their heroes prove worthy to ascend into godhood! 

  

 

Once you've created a world, or joined an existing one online, you'll then be able to choose your first character to play. Each world has been uniquely shaped by the gods and thousands of years of history so your available character options will never be the same! For example, on one world the entire civilization of Dranuk Dwarves may have been wiped out by generations of war with the Analathi Elves. In a world like that, Dranuk Dwarves wouldn't exist and could not be an option. But by the same token, perhaps it was during this war that the art of Necromancy was discovered, opening up class options that make use of that school of magic.

All playable characters also have unique histories and genealogical trees that will determine many of their stats and abilities.

Each character can then also be further customized to suit your personal taste and desired playstyle.

  

 

There are a wide variety of fantasy races possible within each unique world. These are just a few of them. We'll be revealing more over time.

  

 

Hero's Song is deeply rooted in classic RPGs and features a wide variety of classes. Each class offers a distinctly different play style and some will be easier to play than others; allowing you to choose how you want to experience the world. Here are just a few of the classes that may be available on any unique world. We expect to expand this list.

  

 

The world is filled with interesting NPCs and dangerous monsters each designed to function on their own and understand the world around them. Our goal is as much emergent behavior as possible so that no play through will be exactly the same as a previous one.

  

 

Magic takes many forms in the world of Hero's Song, and it's not as simple as different versions of fireballs or magic missiles. There are a variety of magic systems that give magic users a lot of options for gameplay. Magic is something that's very powerful and learning its arcane secrets can be a difficult thing.

  

 

Hero's Song features a robust crafting system. You'll find all sorts of resources and crafting recipes as you explore the world of Hero's Song. We let you craft weapons, armor and even magical items through our enchanting system. Hundreds of different crafting recipes and thousands of resources to find in hard-to-reach places around the world.

Discovery based system
As you find new resources you will discover different recipes based on what you find.

  

 

We got into this business to make great games. We decided to make our business model as simple and fair as possible. There are a lot of great games out there that have microtransactions as a part of them. Many of us on the Development Team have been involved with that business model for years and we decided we wanted Pixelmage Games to be different. Our games will have no microtransactions and they will be reasonably priced. We will offer two versions of Hero's Song. The regular version will be $19.99 and the Deluxe Edition version will be $49.99. The Deluxe Edition includes the soundtrack by Inon Zur, the digital strategy guide and a wallpaper pack. Aside from that there are no differences.

  

 

 

 

What is the game actually about? Is there a main quest? What's my goal?

The game is about living a life of adventure in a world filled with monsters, mysteries and magic to be uncovered. For many, the journey is the goal. Others yearn for their character to ascend to become a God. 

The core of the game is the amazing world that is created anew based on your choices and the history generator that literally creates the entire population of the world with complete history that has real ramifications for passing down skills through bloodlines over time. 

There is no main quest but you'll find plenty of quests and glory. The world is filled with interesting NPCs and dangerous monsters each designed to function on their own and understand the world around them. Our goal is as much emergent behavior as possible so that no play through will be exactly the same as a previous one.

As you explore through the world you level up your character in your chosen class, grow more powerful and discover powerful magical relics of ancient times. 

How is it any different than any other action RPG?

First and foremost our world creation is designed to create a believable fantasy world complete with geography and a history that actually impacts gameplay by actually changing the world itself and determining those races, classes and Gods that will be available. Our goal is to make a fantasy world that feels believeable. That's a very different game than making a story driven RPG. In Hero's Song, the story is actually yours as you adventure through this particular world. This is open world sandbox gaming through and through. 

What influence do the Gods actually have outside of race and class choices and terrain?

The Gods are not merely abstract ideas. They are beings of massive power but they are real and -- although it's incredibly difficult -- they can be killed and the rewards can be rich. They also have tangible impacts on their followers since the magic system for Priests is based on belief.

How do I ascend?

Ascension happens when you reach level 50 and have passed through the Trials.

What is the world like?

You can see the art style from the screenshots and video, but in terms of gameplay, the world is very much a high fantasy style game. That means cities and towns are spread out over vast areas of wilderness. The different races live in different parts of the world: so as you travel you'll encounter different architectures, flora and fauna as you start your character based on your selected race.

The world can also be very, very large. We wanted exploration to be very important so we aren't planning on a ton of simple fast travel. Some of the classes are able to do things (for example, Druids can use Druid rings for their parties) but we wanted travel and the journey itself to matter. During that journey you'll cross deserts, mountains, rivers, swamps and jungles in all kinds of climates. 

You can provision yourself at various shops in the cities and around the world (including wandering vendors). 

The world is also filled with dungeons, caves and many other places to explore and adventure, all of which is generated at the start during world creation.

How does leveling work? 

We use a very traditional class based system with a bunch of classes and races to choose from. You raise in levels by gaining experience through combat, the use of skills and other adventuring related activities.

How about items? 

We have tens of thousands of different items in the game including many different types and categories of weapons (melee and ranged), armor, magic items and artifacts. Items have stats associated with them and many of them have abilities tied to them.

How does multiplayer work?

You can either choose to join a server through our server browser or host a server on your machine. Our goal is to get thousands of players having their data stored on a server with hundreds playing at a time (subject to the machine and bandwidth). 

Playing Multiplayer you'll see people's names above their heads and be able to chat with them (racial language DOES matter here) and you can adventure together (or fight on a PVP server).

What kind of controls do I get if I'm hosting a server?

You'll be able to control who is allowed on the server as well as being able to kick or ban people. In addition, you'll determine which Gods are available, whether it's a PVP server and many other options.

How long is a game session going to last?

Our goal going in is to create a constantly evolving world in which you can get lost.  That means the world won't always be exactly like you left it because things have been going on while you're gone.  Since that's the style of game we're making we think you'll have fun popping in for 20 minutes or playing for hours at a time.

  

 

The Development Team

Pixelmage Games was founded in October of 2015 by a team of veteran game makers. Most members of the team have more than 20 years of experience in the industry – much of that time at Sony Online Entertainment making massively multiplayer games. The list of games that we’ve collectively worked on is broad and includes Tanarus, EverQuest, Planetside, Planetside 2, EverQuest II, Star Wars Galaxies, DC Universe, Shadowrun, Untold Legends, Free Realms, Magic: The Gathering - Tactics, Pox Nora, Clone Wars Adventures, Defiance, Landmark, H1Z1 and many others. 

  
 

Our Partners

In addition to our experienced development team, we are partnering with a few highly respected experts to ensure the Hero's Song experience is as awesome as it can be.

World Building and Design

Patrick Rothfuss
As the New York Times best selling author of The Name of the Wind and other epic fantasy novels, Patrick Rothfuss brings a lifetime of world building and narrative expertise to the Pixelmage team.

CohhCarnage AKA Ben Cassell
On the cutting edge of live streaming entertainment, CohhCarnage is a gamer's gamer.  Cohh brings a fresh point of view to world and game design, with an eye toward how to reward not just the individual player, but the larger community of players and spectators.

Music

Inon Zur
An experience as epic and sweeping as Hero's Song needs an equally epic score. Award-winning composer Inon Zur is the perfect fit for the broad, uplifting mood we strive to inspire. Inon's talent and experience with game scores is second to none.

 

The Pixelmage Philosophy

We formed Pixelmage Games to make the games we want to play. We are huge fans of incredibly deep and immersive game play. We love the 2D pixel art of our youth, freed of all its technical limitations. We also love open worlds and the emergent gameplay that results from layer upon layer of simple rule systems interacting with each other, and love unleashing the player to use his/her tools and abilities in creative ways. We also love and root for our AI creations. We want the denizens of our virtual worlds to be deep and interesting and maybe even respected and feared. We are gamers first, developers second.

You Can Help!

Pixelmage Games has already raised $2.8M in investment. We estimate we're going to need an additional $200k to finish the game. Making an incredibly fun game is our main goal and we need your help. We have a passionate team of professionals building the game they want to play. We will be releasing frequent development updates so that you're well aware of progress that’s being made. Hopefully you'll consider backing Hero’s Song.

Thank you
story_txt:
Also view the 9/23/16 development update video here from Twitch!
 

 
Hero's Song is a hardcore action RPG and uses the familiar click-to-move and attack controls of classic action RPGs like Diablo III or Path of Exile. Combat takes a more measured pace, giving you time to react to the intelligent tactics of your enemies and to thoughtfully deploy your wide variety of skills and abilities. True to its hardcore nature, combat in Hero's Song is dangerous and has very real consequences including the chance of permanent death. Friendly fire is always defaulted to "on", so positioning and precision are very important considerations. Death will come quickly if you think this is a simple clickfest.



 

In Hero's Song players can control their own server and host thousands of other players (with up to hundreds playing at one time.)

Join an existing community or host your own server
Create and control your worlds and make each server truly unique
Decide who gets to play on your server
It's your choice to disallow friendly fire and PvP

story:
Short Summary

Over the past 18 years, Santa Barbara based non-profit AHA! (Attitude. Harmony. Achievement.) has created programs that empower teens to stop bullying, communicate effectively, create peaceful and socially equitable environments, listen deeply and respect diversity, deal with challenging emotions, and make great decisions that lead to their present and future success.

One of the programs that AHA! offers is called Sing it Out. This 16 week journey helps teens to discover the power of community and self expression through musical performance and shared vulnerability. For the past nine months, our small group of filmmakers has passionately documented this process. Filming Sing it Out has been one of the most rewarding and inspiring projects we've ever had the privilege to work on. Join us as we embark on the final editing stage. We need your help to make this film everything we know it has the potential to be.

For more information about AHA! and the work that they do please visit http://ahasb.org 

What We Need 

Our small but committed team has worked on a shoestring budget to film the Sing it Out process over the course of several months. We've shot over 60 hours of footage for the project, but we still need funding to complete the final film. These costs include: follow-up interviews with the kids, film editing, music scoring, color grading, audio mastering, music licensing, legal fees, and festival fees for the film. 

The Impact

During the 16 weeks that we spent filming AHA’s Sing it Out, we were blown away watching how much each of these teens grew just by going through this program. We witnessed them transform into kinder, stronger and more confident individuals than they had ever imagined themselves being.

Through the Sing it Out program, we have watched AHA! change the youth culture here in Santa Barbara into a more inclusive, supportive and welcoming society. We anticipate the film bringing this message to a wide audience through film festivals, media organizations, and online release, in order to transform other communities around the world. And we need your help to make this happen.

Who We Are

Carly Otness is a photographer turned documentary filmmaker based in Santa Barbara, CA. She is originally from New York, where she specialized in fashion, journalism, and music photography. She is enamored with visual storytelling, and Sing It Out has become one of her most rewarding projects to date. You can view her work at www.carlyotness.com. 

Brett Bollier is a professional filmmaker, and co-founder of Culture Spark Media.  He is based in Santa Barbara, CA, where he recently received his Masters of Fine Arts from Brooks Institute. Brett’s experience as a photojournalist, and background in mechanical engineering, has provided much of the structure, storytelling ability, and technical expertise for this project. You can view his work at www.culturesparkmedia.com

Other Ways You Can Help

As struggling artists, we recognize that contributing financially is not always an option. However, there are plenty of other meaningful ways in which you can make a contribution to the production of this film. 

-Share this indiegogo link on any and all social media! 

-Spread the word and encourage your friends to contribute!

It could not be a more relevant or important time in history to share the story of this amazing program, now we just need your support to complete the film, and bring it to audiences around the country!

From Carly Otness and the team at Culture Spark Media, thank you for your support!

story:
"I don't believe people are looking for the meaning of life as much as they are looking for the experience of being alive" -- Joseph Campbell

Who Am I & Why Did I Make This Film?

  • I am a filmmaker, writer, and a business partner with a  music producer.  I have filmed countless songwriting sessions in our music studio with the best songwriters and artists in the music business.  I have also filmed hundred of hours of other artists and entrepreneurs as they work on their craft.  As I silently stand behind my camera, I have been given a VIP access to observe artists at work.  I have seen into their minds and souls a little deeper and with that, I have gained healing and insight.  I want to share that healing and insight with others with my film and with the subsequent online docu-series
  • I am excited about SOUL PROVIDERS because art and artists are vital to our growth and to our experience as human beings.  When I was in my darkest hours in the past couple of years after tragically and unexpectedly losing my best friend and my brother in the same year, it was the artists (those I knew personally and those I didn't know at all), their art, their thought processes, the inspiration for their art, and the execution of their visions that healed my soul and made ME want to create again
  • I filmed ten artists that I was most affected by during this time in my life - music artists, filmmakers, designers, illustrators - who live and work in Los Angeles, and I can't wait to share their insights, personalities, creative inspirations, and sage advice with the world.  I truly believe this film will speak to other artists and art lovers worldwide. 
  • I've already completed the bulk of the project.  I now need help to get it out into the world.  That's where you can be my rock star! 
  • This is a special time in the SOUL PROVIDERS overall project (which includes the feature film and the later online docu-series) because this is a time that YOU can get involved and be a part of the film, forever.  There is even an opportunity for artists to get a FEATURED ROLE in the future SOUL PROVIDERS docu-series! This is when you can get your name in the credits, score tickets to screenings, get feedback on YOUR artistic projects, and even have dinner with ME. (I'm fun, I promise!) Any contribution level will forever be etched in my heart.  You will be a BIG part in making sure this film didn't die in my hard drive.  
  • Your contribution - big or small - will help me get this film out to as many film festivals as possible, starting with the most prestigious and best matched for this film, all the way down to the festivals in small towns for dedicated local film lovers  
  • With your contribution, I will also be able to start production on the SOUL PROVIDERS docu-series which will spotlight other artists worldwide.  There is also an opportunity right now, for a limited time and limited to only 10 people, to be FEATURED in the SOUL PROVIDERS docu-series! The first of the series will be the Los Angeles artists from the feature film, but the docu-series will include bonus footage not shown in the film.  All other subsequent series will include artists from all over the United States and the world!  (And maybe YOU!) I'm so excited to get out and film artists in other locations around the world!  

`

Just like what my "Free Hugs In Hollywood" video did for people worldwide when it went viral on YouTube and on Yahoo! (and earned me a Yahoo! Veddy Award & as well as my story of making the video featured in  the Chicken Soul For The Soul: Manifestation book), I believe SOUL PROVIDERS can do for art and artists!  

FREE HUGS IN HOLLYWOOD - shot & edited by me :-)

Soul Providers Roll-Out 

"I think art, music, creativity...are so very vital to the advancement of us as human beings" - Lee England Jr., Musician/Music Producer

With the SOUL PROVIDERS feature film already completely shot (yay!) and 80% of the way through post-production (whaaaat!?), I am raising money now to:

  1. Enter the film into film festivals & initial marketing costs
  2. Start production on the SOUL PROVIDERS docu-series which will be released online after the film's official release - the docu-series will include footage from the feature film as well as additional footage originally shot of each subject which is not included in the film
  3. Start pre-preproduction on future SOUL PROVIDERS docu-series! I will film artists in other locations - featuring artists in New York, San Francisco & the Bay Area, Paris, London, and more.  I already have subjects lined up in each city/region and I'm excited to see what new dimensions the participants in differing locations adds to the SOUL PROVIDERS canvas!  Each artist furthering the interest in art and artists worldwide, inspiring future art, artists, and supporters of art!

"I love having an idea, a musical idea in my head, and being able to realize it" - Dapo Torimiro, Artist/Music Producer

"I believe art is EVERYTHING" - Onch, Designer

"Art is such an important piece of the planet Earth" - Ivory, Artist/Songwriter/Illustrator

"The best thing about what I do for a living is that I guess I feel I have some sort of purpose" - Oren Yoel, Music Producer

The Film Festival Plan...

  • We have a film festival plan that prioritizes the film festivals.  From the most prestigious/most perfect match for this film, all the way down to just the supportive film goers festivals, we will put funds first towards the festivals with potentially the biggest impact and then work our way down from there based on how much we raise.  
  • Sometimes by getting into the bigger festivals, smaller festivals send you an invite and your entry fee is waived.  If that happens, that's more money to go towards the docu-series! 
  • We will continue to add fundraising perks over the course of this campaign based on how much we raise, so check back often!

"I think art is really important. It's the only thing in life that can bring joy to people" - Ester Brym, Filmmaker/Editor

"Art and music and every other kind of expression, those are the kinds of things that really keep us together" - Jarell Perry, Artist/Songwriter

"I think what's great about it, is that it offers me a deeper understanding of who I am" - Julia Huffman, Filmmaker/Activist

"It's my go-to 'peace'" - Stephanie Owens, Actress/DIYer

"I believe that art is seriously, the best currency we have in the world" - Scotty Grand, Artist/Songwriter

Other Ways You Can Help

Sometimes, we just can't contribute, believe me, I get it!  But that doesn't mean you can't help! 

  • Help us make some noise about our campaign! 
  • Share this page on your social media sites!
  • Tell your friends about this film, docu-series, and campaign! (Maybe this will strike a cord with them and THEY will contribute!)
  • Like the film's Facebook page!
  • Send us a positive note! (Hey, every thing helps!)

Did you get this far?  Wow... you're a great supporter of artists and dreamers - time is our most precious asset and I am incredibly honored you read my fundraising campaign in all the way through!  Thank you!
story_txt:
"I don't believe people are looking for the meaning of life as much as they are looking for the experience of being alive" -- Joseph Campbell
Who Am I & Why Did I Make This Film?

I am a filmmaker, writer, and a business partner with a  music producer.  I have filmed countless songwriting sessions in our music studio with the best songwriters and artists in the music business.  I have also filmed hundred of hours of other artists and entrepreneurs as they work on their craft.  As I silently stand behind my camera, I have been given a VIP access to observe artists at work.  I have seen into their minds and souls a little deeper and with that, I have gained healing and insight.  I want to share that healing and insight with others with my film and with the subsequent online docu-series
I am excited about SOUL PROVIDERS because art and artists are vital to our growth and to our experience as human beings.  When I was in my darkest hours in the past couple of years after tragically and unexpectedly losing my best friend and my brother in the same year, it was the artists (those I knew personally and those I didn't know at all), their art, their thought processes, the inspiration for their art, and the execution of their visions that healed my soul and made ME want to create again
I filmed ten artists that I was most affected by during this time in my life - music artists, filmmakers, designers, illustrators - who live and work in Los Angeles, and I can't wait to share their insights, personalities, creative inspirations, and sage advice with the world.  I truly believe this film will speak to other artists and art lovers worldwide. 
I've already completed the bulk of the project.  I now need help to get it out into the world.  That's where you can be my rock star!

I'm so excited to get out and film artists in other locations around the world!

story:
My name is David Whitt,

I’m a community organizer and the director of Ground Zero: Ferguson. I was living in the neighborhood during the time Mike Brown was killed. This police shooting led to the most widespread unrest in the United States since the Civil Rights era. It catalyzed the slogans Hand Up, Don't Shoot! and Black Lives Matter, and sparked a nationwide conversation about police brutality and racism in law enforcement. Since then, we have witnessed many similar police murders captured by citizen cameras in cities across the country. But while affected communities continue to struggle for justice, authorities and the media respond to these police killings in a manner that systematically avoids conversations about real solutions. More importantly, the people most impacted by these killings are least likely to be included in these conversations.

The real solution lies in listening to the stories of real people. I started to collect the unheard voices of Ferguson by filming interviews with residents of my community. This documentary tells their version of what happened and their vision for what needs to happen. But to fully and authentically capture these voices, I need your support. Join this campaign, and help me complete this film, so this story can be shared with audiences everywhere.

The film will weave together a broad collection of interviews with first-hand witnesses, local residents, community organizers, and law enforcement representatives into a thematic narrative of collective reflection. Some of these voices take us back to the experience of living in a neighborhood that was literally being barricaded and under siege by local, state, and federal law enforcement agencies, assisted by the Army National Guard. Others will tell the story of a community memorial built in the middle of the road where Michael Brown was killed. As mourners came from everywhere to pay their respects, this memorial started to become a point of contention in community-police relations. It was run over several times and even burnt down at one point. I will never forget the day I woke up to the smoldering memorial with police standing idly by as it was burning.

But Ground Zero: Ferguson also tells the story of a neighborhood that found real solutions. You'll meet the residents of Canfield Greens who stopped police brutality by coming together and creating their own systems of justice and mutual accountability after police decided they would no longer patrol the area for one year after the August 2014 shooting. They'll tell you how people came together, and which struggles they endured in resisting the institutions that were supposed to fix, not perpetuate, the problem.

This documentary begins and ends in Ferguson, but takes it takes the viewer on excursions to North Charleston, Baltimore, Oakland, and Staten Island to highlight similarities and explore differences to other high-profile videotaped police killings. In doing so, we reflect on common patterns of ( mis)representation and strategies used to divide the public in the wake of these incidents. We examine the so-called Ferguson Effect, widely publicized in the public narrative by leading figures including former FBI director James Comey. This is the idea that increased scrutiny of law enforcement by citizens equipped with video cameras will lead to more crime because the police are undermined in their effectiveness. Since 2014, studies have repeatedly found no evidence of a Ferguson Effect with respect to crime, or the number of officers killed on duty. Yet in 2018, sensationalist media continue to ask such ill-informed questions as “Is the ‘Ferguson Effect’ to blame for the carnage in Chicago?”.

Ultimately, Ground Zero: Ferguson is a documentary that highlights the need to struggle for public space in the wake of police tragedies: the fight for physical space to come together, the fight for narrative space to be heard, and the fight for political space to find solutions.

The Team

David Whitt is a filmmaker, activist, and community organizer from St. Louis, MO. He is the founder of the Canfield Watchmen, a cop-watch movement created in the Ferguson neighborhood where Mike Brown was killed. He is also a founding member of the St. Louis First Responders, a network of lawyers, activists, and community members that responds to police shootings. David is a trainer and on-the-ground coordinator for WeCopwatch, and regularly travels cross-country to support other groups and initiatives.

Jacob Crawford is a filmmaker, journalist, and veteran activist. He is executive producer of the 2017 documentary Copwatch, and also creator of These Streets Are Watching, the first in-the-streets, non-dramatized know-your-rights training video (released in 2004). Outside of film, Jacob has worked as a professional investigator for a law firm that successfully sued the Oakland Police Department in multiple cases over the span of three years, securing a total settlement value of nearly $10 million for plaintiffs. He has extensive experience in the assembly and presentation of evidence, and has incorporated this knowledge into his journalism and film work.

Patrick Hamm is an award-winning documentary filmmaker and founder of Bulldog Agenda, a Berlin-based production company. A 2018 Berlinale Talents alumnus, he most recently completed Freedom For the Wolf, an epic investigation into the global rise of illiberal democracy, which took him to the frontlines of protest movements around the world. He is also executive producer of Copwatch, which tells the true story of WeCopwatch, an organization dedicated to filming police activity as a non-violent form of protest and deterrent to police brutality. Patrick holds a Ph.D. in Sociology from Harvard University and a B.A. in Ethics, Politics & Economics from Yale University.

Andreas Brinck is a digital activist and experienced online campaigner. Following a private sector career in online marketing, he now manages social media campaigns for NGO clients like climate advocacy networks 350.org and FossilFree. He is a longtime climate justice organizer, and currently runs a popular news and live-streaming portal that reports on the resistance against open-pit coal mining in Germany. Andreas visited Ferguson as a Heinrich Böll Foundation Welcoming Communities Awardee in 2016. He holds a B.A. in Business Administration from Boston University.

We are grateful for our partners at WITNESS for their mentorship and ongoing support of this project.

The Campaign

Unfortunately, making real films costs real money. We need to raise a minimum total of $45,000 to complete this film. Your donations will allow us to film the remaining scenes and interviews, to hire the necessary post-production specialists, to license third-party footage, and to promote the film after its release. Because Ground Zero: Ferguson challenges existing narratives, it’s important that we steer clear of reductionist mainstream discourse, and we can only do that if we stay independent of the constraints that come with traditional film financing.

If you choose to support our campaign, we got a number of cool perks for you! Depending on the level of your contribution, you will receive screen credits, limited edition apparel, or early access to a digital download of the film. For higher-level donors we offer gifts like VIP tickets to the premiere or an individual Q&A with the filmmakers. And for anyone choosing to donate at one of our producer levels – you receive the full perk package and we consider you to be a member of our team.

All contributions matter, and even if you can only donate $10, you’ll receive a shoutout on our social media channels and receive regular insider updates from the campaign.

This campaign is a flexible campaign. That means If we don’t raise the entire goal amount, we still receive the funds from all committed donors. In that event that this will happen, our contingency plan is to use the funds that we receive to complete the remaining interviews and location shoots in the most economical way, and to hire an assistant editor that we can afford. This will allow us to complete a rough cut of the film, which we can then use to fundraise for our remaining post-production expenses.

Other Ways You Can Help

We understand that not everyone has the means to contribute to our campaign. But you can still help! Perhaps you know a friend who might be interested in donating? Use the share buttons to recommend this campaign to others. You can also participate by following us on social media and receiving updates about the film. And because this is a community-driven project, we would also love to hear directly from you.

story:
Summary

Howdy Folks, 

My name is Lauryn Eisenstein, writer and director of Goodnight, Cowboy, my BFA thesis film at Columbia College Hollywood. For the past decade, I have been writing, directing, and producing films, which have earned me film festival wins, competitions, exclusive classes and workshops, and mentorship from the actor Burt Reynolds. I want this to be the best film I've made yet, because it holds a very special place in my heart and I have put all my blood, sweat, and tears into it over the last seven months and will continue to do so until it's completed.

Goodnight, Cowboy is a cross-generational film about REAGAN TAYLOR (20s),a reserved and quiet home healthcare nurse who’s afraid of commitments and spends her days taking care of old dying patients to avoid her real truth. Her current patient is JETT WILDER (70s), a dying washed-up actor and free-spirited prankster. The two form an unlikely friendship filled with unexpected adventures, nostalgia, and understanding of each others lives. When Jett becomes more ill he decides that he's lived a full life and wants to die, but can't go through with killing himself. Jett's inability to kill himself forces him to request that Reagan assist in his suicide. Reagan being the person she is; a person who helps people live not die has to decide to either go against everything she believes in as a care-giver to help him die with the dignity he has left or not do anything and let him die suffering from an illness that will make his fun and exciting personality unrecognizable. Having this decision forces her to accept his friendship and love for her and acknowledge her love for him in return. Goodnight, Cowboy at its core is about the the ability to create your own family  and the sacrifices one makes for love.

This film isn't just any film to me; it's a  testament to the strong friendships I've made with people much older than myself and highlights the lessons I've learned so far in life. Goodnight, Cowboy is not just my thesis film;  it represents the films I want to create throughout my career as writer, director and producer, which is why it is near and dear to my heart. 

What We Need & What You Get

Goodnight, Cowboy is extremely complex and expensive, and in order to ensure that it be the best it can be, we need your help! My producers and I spent days hand-picking each and every person working on this film I have spent days with each department head to carefully discuss every element that will be involved during all phases of production. The departments that are most important to us include, but are not limited to:

  • Camera Department
  • Art Department
  • Production Department
  • Post Production Department

Most of the budget will be allocated to production design, locations, and wardrobe. The film pays homage to the style of golden age Hollywood classics and Westerns. With that said the production department requires very specific and eclectic props. Locations are the most expensive element of this film. They include:

  • A Western Ranch
  • A Hollywood Hills Mansion
  • Hospital 
  • Park
  • 1960s Convertible car

The actors not only have to act their parts, they have to look their parts too. This requires not only casual clothing, but also the clothing items that we dreamed about as children when we dressed up as cowboys and cowgirls. In addition to wardrobe, the funds we raise will be used for:

  • Equipment
  • Makeup
  • Scoring (Music)
  • Transportation
  • Art Materials 
  • Craft Services and catering (food for the cast and crew)
  • Production Vehicle Insurance

Your help is more appreciated then you will ever know, but to show some of that gratitude, every contribution comes with a specific and unique perk chosen to fit the theme and style of Goodnight, Cowboy. When thinking about style of my film, think of films like Million Dollar Baby , The Good, the Bad, and the Ugly, Sunset Boulevard – even Harold and Maude.

Your contribution to this film makes you apart of it too. You may not be holding the boom (microphone) or pressing record on the camera, but you are equally just as important as the people who do because without you there will be no boom or camera. Please review the perks available to you with each level of donation on the right side of the screen! With your help we can make this film not just a dream, but a reality!

The Impact

By making a contribution to help make this film possible, you will be making the biggest impact of all because you've not only helped me and my film -- but you are investing in my future as well every other filmmaker's future who has the chance to work on this wonderful film. I'm lucky to say that I've had a very successful journey as a student filmmaker so far and I would so love if you could help me continue that success as I venture out into the business as a writer and filmmaker in Hollywood.

Other Ways You Can Help

If you don't have the funds to contribute to our film, there are other ways you can help us reach our goal:

  • Spread the word to your family, friends, and colleagues 
  • Share on social media (Facebook, Instagram, Twitter, Snapchat, and LinkedIn). Use the hashtags, #GoodnightCowboy and #thesisfilm
  • Like our social media pages on Facebook and Instagram
  • If you think you have an eclectic prop that you don't mind lending to us, reach out. We will treat your belongings as if they were our own. 
  • If you know someone or a company that would be interested in sponsoring us, can you put us in touch?

That's all Folks!

Thank you from the bottom of my heart,

Lauryn Eisenstein

and the Goodnight, Cowboy cast and crew
story_txt:
Summary
Howdy Folks, 
My name is Lauryn Eisenstein, writer and director of Goodnight, Cowboy, my BFA thesis film at Columbia College Hollywood. For the past decade, I have been writing, directing, and producing films, which have earned me film festival wins, competitions, exclusive classes and workshops, and mentorship from the actor Burt Reynolds. I want this to be the best film I've made yet, because it holds a very special place in my heart and I have put all my blood, sweat, and tears into it over the last seven months and will continue to do so until it's completed.
Goodnight, Cowboy is a cross-generational film about REAGAN TAYLOR (20s),a reserved and quiet home healthcare nurse who’s afraid of commitments and spends her days taking care of old dying patients to avoid her real truth. Her current patient is JETT WILDER (70s), a dying washed-up actor and free-spirited prankster. The two form an unlikely friendship filled with unexpected adventures, nostalgia, and understanding of each others lives. When Jett becomes more ill he decides that he's lived a full life and wants to die, but can't go through with killing himself. Jett's inability to kill himself forces him to request that Reagan assist in his suicide. Reagan being the person she is; a person who helps people live not die has to decide to either go against everything she believes in as a care-giver to help him die with the dignity he has left or not do anything and let him die suffering from an illness that will make his fun and exciting personality unrecognizable. Having this decision forces her to accept his friendship and love for her and acknowledge her love for him in return. Goodnight, Cowboy at its core is about the the ability to create your own family  and the sacrifices one makes for love.
This film isn't just any film to me; it's a  testament to the strong friendships I've made with people much older than myself and highlights the lessons I've learned so far in life. Goodnight, Cowboy is not just my thesis film;  it represents the films I want to create throughout my career as writer, director and producer, which is why it is near and dear to my heart. 

What We Need & What You Get
Goodnight, Cowboy is extremely complex and expensive, and in order to ensure that it be the best it can be, we need your help! My producers and I spent days hand-picking each and every person working on this film I have spent days with each department head to carefully discuss every element that will be involved during all phases of production. The departments that are most important to us include, but are not limited to:

Camera Department
Art Department
Production Department
Post Production Department

Most of the budget will be allocated to production design, locations, and wardrobe. The film pays homage to the style of golden age Hollywood classics and Westerns. With that said the production department requires very specific and eclectic props. Locations are the most expensive element of this film. They include:

A Western Ranch
A Hollywood Hills Mansion
Hospital 
Park
1960s Convertible car

The actors not only have to act their parts, they have to look their parts too. This requires not only casual clothing, but also the clothing items that we dreamed about as children when we dressed up as cowboys and cowgirls. In addition to wardrobe, the funds we raise will be used for:

Equipment
Makeup
Scoring (Music)
Transportation
Art Materials 
Craft Services and catering (food for the cast and crew)
Production Vehicle Insurance

Your help is more appreciated then you will ever know, but to show some of that gratitude, every contribution comes with a specific and unique perk chosen to fit the theme and style of Goodnight, Cowboy. When thinking about style of my film, think of films like Million Dollar Baby , The Good, the Bad, and the Ugly, Sunset Boulevard – even Harold and Maude.
Your contribution to this film makes you apart of it too. You may not be holding the boom (microphone) or pressing record on the camera, but you are equally just as important as the people who do because without you there will be no boom or camera. Please review the perks available to you with each level of donation on the right side of the screen! With your help we can make this film not just a dream, but a reality!

The Impact
By making a contribution to help make this film possible, you will be making the biggest impact of all because you've not only helped me and my film -- but you are investing in my future as well every other filmmaker's future who has the chance to work on this wonderful film. I'm lucky to say that I've had a very successful journey as a student filmmaker so far and I would so love if you could help me continue that success as I venture out into the business as a writer and filmmaker in Hollywood.

Other Ways You Can Help
If you don't have the funds to contribute to our film, there are other ways you can help us reach our goal:

Spread the word to your family, friends, and colleagues 
Share on social media (Facebook, Instagram, Twitter, Snapchat, and LinkedIn). Use the hashtags, #GoodnightCowboy and #thesisfilm
Like our social media pages on Facebook and Instagram
If you think you have an eclectic prop that you don't mind lending to us, reach out. We will treat your belongings as if they were our own. 
If you know someone or a company that would be interested in sponsoring us, can you put us in touch?

That's all Folks!
Thank you from the bottom of my heart,
Lauryn Eisenstein
and the Goodnight, Cowboy cast and crew

story:
THE PLOT

Unforgettable is a story about two desperate people of very different ages and backgrounds, coming together in difficult stages of their lives. All we need is a friend to rely on, and that’s what we come to understand when Charley Gray, a 21-year-old thief, and Albert Crook, a grieving 81-year-old, find themselves bound together in the same house, which Charley originally tried to ransack. Through sharing confessions, with the occasional twist and turn, what starts out as a last resort suicide attempt, turns into a blossoming friendship between the two unlikeliest of personalities and one that we hope will last forever.

 

THE PROJECT STORY

Since January, Graded Films has been working closely with Phil Davis, a recent graduate in screenplay, to create a story that captures honesty and reality, in a friendship between the unlikeliest of people. Our primary aim was to create something that audiences can relate to, highlighting very topical issues within our modern society today. We also wanted to narrow the view finder, and concentrate on the characters within the film, allowing us as the audience to explore and understand them, in the hope that we become more aware of the issues raised, as a result of the screenplay. Ed Waller is to compose a complete soundtrack to the film, making it a truly unique piece of film.

Graded Films was established by young budding film makers, Freddie Hill and Tom Carter, both students with the big ambition of creating a full blown short film, the two are proud to present Unforgettable, alongside their team of fellow creatives.

Unforgettable, written by Phil Davis, will be directed by Freddie Hill, followed by Jacob Thomas as Executive Producer, Ed Waller as composer, and Tom Carter as Director of Photography.

To create such a production, Graded Films need your help to ensure that they can produce the very best film. By sponsoring Graded Films, every aspect of the pre-production and post production will be covered, enabling the team to get the honest and thought-provoking outcome that the story truly deserves.

To show our appreciation for your donation, we would like to give something back to you. Each level of donation has its own reward from us.

 

WRITTEN & DIRECTED

Both passionately invested Filmmakers, Phil Davis, a recent graduate in screenplay, and Freddie Hill, an abstract and contemporary art student and designer, take on the story of Unforgettable. For the two, this is their first big scale project, with Phil having completed several YouTube based writes and other smaller based projects, he is here to make his mark with Unforgettable. Freddie also too has worked on similar projects, and is now currently Assistant Director on Dick Whittington the Pantomime, and will be the Director of Puppetry in a new Fringe play in January. 

 

CINEMATOGRAPHY

The team are looking for something rather unique, unseen in the short film industry, rarely in big block busters either. Tom Carter (cinematographer and editor) and Freddie Hill (director) will be pushing the boundaries of camera movement, aiming to create seamless, tied together shots that appear as one linear narrative journey. Cuts and breaks will be used rarely, and if so, for effect. 

'Fluidity' and 'Journey' were two words made clear in Freddie's plan. With this, the team hope to take the audience on a journey from the moment we are fired into the film, allowing us access into the lives of the two who are spotlighted in this brilliantly written drama.

story:
1960's. Cuba. CHE GUEVARA, one of the main architects of the Cuban revolution with Fidel Castro, struggles to settle into a normal life as a husband, father and a bureaucrat. Driven by his sense of internationalist duty, he wants to export his guerrilla warfare techniques in other parts of Latin America.

Congo. LARRY DEVLIN, an ambitious Second World War veteran is appointed CIA station chief. Washington needs the Congo for its uranium and the cobalt. Devlin hates communism and is prepared to do everything in his power to ensure Congo does not fall into hands of the Soviet Union. PATRICE LUMUMBA, the Marxist revolutionary and first democratically elected Prime Minister of Congo, is a thorn on the side of the USA administration with his radical anti imperialist rhetoric. Devlin works with the country army chief JOSEPH MOBUTU. Lumumba is assassinated with the help of CIA, M16 and Belgian intelligence.

Che addresses the United Nation General Assembly in New York and refers to Lumumba as a martyr and calls for the free people of the world to avenge the crime of the Congo. Soon after his speech, with the blessings of Castro, Che goes on a two-month tour of eight African countries where he meets leaders of revolutionary movements. His aim is to create an international movement to fight imperialism. LAURENT KABILA, 26 years old, a Marxist rebel leader, makes an impression on Che. Kabila agrees with Che about the need to fight imperialism; and also his forces have already captured two thirds of the Congo. Che offers him help.

Che returns to Cuba an inspired man. In a meeting with Castro, he makes a case for Cuba to support revolutionary movements across the globe. While Castro is in agreement with Che and willing to offer logistics and training, he is shocked when Che tells him he wants to leave Cuba and lead a revolution in Bolivia. Castro warns him about Bolivia. The political climate there is not ready for a revolution. He advises Che to go to Congo. Castro wants him to prepare and familiarize himself with the conditions in Congo, but Che is impatient. Aware the CIA wants to assassinate him, Che decides not to communicate with Kabila about his intention to come fight in Congo.

Che puts on a disguise. He shaves his entire head and beard, puts on a pair of black-framed eyeglasses and inserts prosthesis in his mouth to alter the shape of his face.

Che leaves behind his wife, ALEIDA MARCH and their children. Aleida is sick with anxious, not knowing if she will ever see her husband again. Che receives a message from his mother who lives in Argentina. She is feeling her age and would like to see him; but Che is convinced his mission is more important.

When Che arrives at the Eastern part of the Congo to meet with Kabila, but the Congolese guerrilla leader is away in Egypt. Also the situation has changed dramatically since the last two met. Kabila no longer controls two thirds of the country. Che finds an embattled rebel group that is profoundly demoralized.

Kabila is happy the Cuban soldiers are in Congo but not Che. He is afraid Che’s presence will attract the attention of the USA government with disastrous results. He instructs Che not to reveal his identity. Later he gets news that his mother has died. He is overwhelmed with sadness and remorse, but conceals this in public, with a show of strength and resolution.

Kabila wants to attack the military garrison and a hydroelectric plant at Fort Bendera. Che is against the attack as it carries a huge risk and it will expose the presence of the Cuban soldiers. There are 300 enemy soldiers and 100 mercenaries at the military garrison. Kabila insists. Che shares his armed guerilla techniques theory but the rebels are not interested. They put their faith on a Dawa, a traditional medicine man to help them become invisible during the battle. They are also superstitious and refuse to dig trenches for protection; holes are to bury the dead. Che is dismissive, which angers the rebels. He is arrogant and they want him to leave. Castro sends a message to Che saying he must be patient with the rebels and must not lose hope. Che writes back to Castro. He has made a profound mistake, Kabila is not a revolutionary. He does not come to the battlefront  with his men, but prefers to stay at expensive hotels with different women.  

Che remains behind while the Cuban soldiers and the rebels launch an attack. The enemy proves tough. The rebels drop their arms and run away. Four Cuban soldiers are killed and their retreating comrades are forced to leave their bodies behind. Che is devastated. The Cuban soldiers are demoralized and demand to go back home. Che threatens to shoot any of the Cuban soldiers who desert.

Larry Devlin retrieves a diary from one of the dead Cuban soldiers. He discovers there are Cuban soldiers assisting the rebels. Devlin’s informants also reveal the presence of Che, a figurehead of socialist revolution. Devlin offers Mobutu’s army reinforcements. Mobutu’s army begins to bomb the rebel area.

Castro sends a message to Che to pull out of Congo. The Organisation of African Unity has called for all the foreign forces including the Cubans to leave Congo. Che does not want to leave the country. Consumed by an overwhelming sense of failure, he tries to inspire the Cuban soldiers. He tells them to always maintain their fighting spirit, as there is still so much to do to combat injustice and oppression across the world.

3 November 1966: Che leaves Cuba for Bolivia. Aleida and the children bids him tearful farewell. It is a painful separation but Che is in his element again, elated to be embarking on another revolutionary mission. He sees going into Bolivia as a way to redeem his failure in the Congo.

BIOGRAPHY

I am a South African filmmakers whose films, TV dramas and documentaries have been screened at film festivals and venues such as Toronto International Film Festival, Sydney Film Festival, Durban International Film Festival, New York African Film Festival, Berlin International Film Festival and International Documentary Film Festival of Amsterdam (IDFA) and Hotdocs in Toronto. My work has been screened on BBC (British Broadcasting Corporation), Arte (Germany/France), NHK (Japan), DR (Denmark), Black Entertainment Television (BET), SABC (South African Broadcasting Corporation) and YLE (Finland). Examples of my works are ‘’When we were Black’’, a four part TV drama series about a young boy who wants to lose his virginity against the backdrop of the 1976 student uprisings, ‘’Conversations on a Sunday Afternoon’’ about a writer who is searching for a refugee from Somalia, ‘’Nelson Mandela the Myth and Me, ’’  a feature documentary that unpacks the myth of Nelson Mandela, and ‘’The Number,’’ a prison movie about a gang leader searching for redemption.

CONTRIBUTIONS 

I am going to use the money to do research and write the script for a period of a year starting in December 2017 to December 2018 and also to pay the script editor. The research will include trips to the Congo and Cuba to interview soldiers who knew Che Guevara. I would like to turn the interviews into a book like we did with the Nelson Mandela documentary. Will give a signed copy of the book to all the contributors. 

If the film makes money, I will return all the contributions plus 10% return on the investment. Contributors who invest $1000 and more, will receive co-producer credit and those who invest $5000 and more will receive executive producer credit.

story:
Über das Projekt

 
 
  • Wir wollen Film revolutionieren und das wird erst der Anfang!
  • Die Geschichte handelt von Alex Sandner ein Patient von Psychiater Dr. Ronginson.
    In den Sitzungen erzählt er von seinen Problemen und berichtet über seine Vorstellungen. Er bringt den Therapeuten Dr. Ronginson dazu selbst über seine geheimen Probleme zu sprechen. Den zu Beginn sehr ausgewogenen und souveränen Therapeuten scheinen eine Menge Dinge zu plagen und auf der Seele zu brennen. Hauptsächlich seine Vergangenheit in der er seine Frau und seinen kleinen Sohn im Stich ließ um ein neues Leben und eine neue Familie zu gründen. 

 

  • Um diese spannende Geschichte auf die beste Weise erzählen zu können brauchen wir neben viel Gehirnschmalz und harter Arbeit auch - wie sollte es anders sein - Geld. Hier kommst du ins Spiel!  
 
 

 

Was du uns gibst & was du bekommst

  

 

  • Unsere Kosten bestehen aus:

 

  • Szenenbild (Farbe, Möbel, Requisiten, etc.)
  • Kostüm 
  • Transport (des Equipments sowie der Darsteller und der Crew)
  • Unterkunft der Darsteller für die Drehzeit von fünf Tagen
  • Der Verpflegung der Crew und des Casts während der fünf Drehtage 

 

  • Wer von der Idee eines spannenden und emotionalen deutschen Kurzfilms begeistert ist und dazu beitragen möchte, dem bieten wir im Gegenzug spannende Perks an.

 

Wir stellen uns vor:

 

Dies ist nur das Kernteam hinter "Die Therapie", es stecken aber noch viel mehr Talente dahinter!

 

 

 

 

Was kommt danach?  

  • Mit unserem Film werden wir auf nationalen und internationalen Festivals vertreten sein und den deutschen Film der nächsten Generation repräsentieren.  

 

 

 

Herausforderungen

 

 

  • Nicht immer läuft alles wie geplant, deshalb können sich einige der Deadlines um wenige Wochen verschieben. Wir arbeiten jedoch unermüdlich an diesem Projekt, so dass so ein Fall nur aufgrund von finanzieller Knappheit eintreten würde. 
 

 

 

Andere Wege, wie man helfen kann

 

Wenn du gerne helfen möchtest, aber gerade nicht flüssig bist, gibt es noch andere Wege dies zu tun: 

 

  • Sprich über uns!
  • Teile diese Kampagne mit Freunden!
