Über das Projekt  Wir wollen Film revolutionieren und das wird erst der Anfang!
Die Geschichte handelt von Alex Sandner ein Patient von Psychiater Dr. Ronginson.In den Sitzungen erzählt er von seinen Problemen und berichtet über seine Vorstellungen. Er bringt den Therapeuten Dr. Ronginson dazu selbst über seine geheimen Probleme zu sprechen. Den zu Beginn sehr ausgewogenen und souveränen Therapeuten scheinen eine Menge Dinge zu plagen und auf der Seele zu brennen. Hauptsächlich seine Vergangenheit in der er seine Frau und seinen kleinen Sohn im Stich ließ um ein neues Leben und eine neue Familie zu gründen. 
 
Um diese spannende Geschichte auf die beste Weise erzählen zu können brauchen wir neben viel Gehirnschmalz und harter Arbeit auch - wie sollte es anders sein - Geld. Hier kommst du ins Spiel!     
Was du uns gibst & was du bekommst   
Unsere Kosten bestehen aus:
 


Szenenbild (Farbe, Möbel, Requisiten, etc.)
Kostüm 
Transport (des Equipments sowie der Darsteller und der Crew)
Unterkunft der Darsteller für die Drehzeit von fünf Tagen

Der Verpflegung der Crew und des Casts während der fünf Drehtage 


 
Wer von der Idee eines spannenden und emotionalen deutschen Kurzfilms begeistert ist und dazu beitragen möchte, dem bieten wir im Gegenzug spannende Perks an.
 
Wir stellen uns vor:
 
Dies ist nur das Kernteam hinter "Die Therapie", es stecken aber noch viel mehr Talente dahinter!
 
 
  
Was kommt danach?  


Mit unserem Film werden wir auf nationalen und internationalen Festivals vertreten sein und den deutschen Film der nächsten Generation repräsentieren.  

 
 
 Herausforderungen  

Nicht immer läuft alles wie geplant, deshalb können sich einige der Deadlines um wenige Wochen verschieben. Wir arbeiten jedoch unermüdlich an diesem Projekt, so dass so ein Fall nur aufgrund von finanzieller Knappheit eintreten würde.    Andere Wege, wie man helfen kann Wenn du gerne helfen möchtest, aber gerade nicht flüssig bist, gibt es noch andere Wege dies zu tun: 
 

Sprich über uns!

Teile diese Kampagne mit Freunden!

story:
Abi is a short sci-fi horror film about a scientist named Vincent Forrester who creates an organic computer with the help of his assistants Abi and Julie.  A catastrophic virus has infected the prototype bio-processing system, and as they race to save their work, the virus jumps from computer to human and infects Abi.  Now her violent madness puts much more than careers at risk...

We love making movies, especially the kind of genre films we grew up with.   We've loved sci-fi and horror movies pretty much since we understood what movies were.  Monsters, spaceships, mad scientists, things that go bump in the night-- these were the films we were drawn to, and naturally these are the films we want to make as well.

So Abi is 100% a love letter to all those genre influences we wear on our sleeves.  Abi is the kind of film we want to watch, and we hope it's a film you'll want to watch too. 

There's nothing better for a filmmaker than sharing their movie with an audience where the oohs, aaahs, and screams all come at just the right place.  We want you to experience that good feeling too!

Working in the film industry for our day jobs, we hold ourselves to the same professional standards when we go out to make a film.  We've self-funded previous projects, including the monster movie Ding Dong (https://youtu.be/I39HLAjyUzc) that played festivals across the country. 

Abi is the next step, and it's much more ambitious.

We're trying to put images on the screen that are both incredible and original, and to do them practically.  Vincent's organic computer will be a showstopper if we fulfill our goals.  Add to that stunts, makeup fx, blood effects... not to mention the gear to light and shoot them at a pro level.

Risks and Challenges

The challenges of this project are ones we've set for ourselves:  make it look good.  We've worked on the script for over a year, and we'll keep trying to improve it right up through shooting.  Bringing it to life in the way we know it should be done is why we chose to start a campaign.  But if we fall short of our goal, we'll still make the film as good as we can with the resources we have.  That's what indie film-making is all about.

We're looking to raise $14,000, to add to the money we've have already pledged to the project.  We've got skin in the game ourselves!

That money is going to:

 

As you can see, production design far outweighs anything besides paying the professional actors we've cast.  That's how it should be in a genre movie-- we want you to believe this world from beginning to end.  Even though we have the (highly discounted) help of a lot of our friends who work in the Chicago film community, they need the supplies and materials to create those fantastic images you love to see.

 

Timothy Troy, Dan McGuire, and Corey Gilbert are filmmakers based out of Chicago.  

Tim and Dan met at Columbia College Chicago in the early 2000s, when Dan's script for a short horror film called Dorothy Greene fell into Tim's hands and became one of his earliest directing projects.  We became great friends (roommates for a few years, too) and collaborators, constantly trading ideas, work, and good-natured ribbing.

Corey got involved in the project after Tim and Dan's previous project Ding Dong screened at DragonCon in 2017.  He and Tim realized that they both lived in Chicago, and hit it off.  Corey, who has produced a slew of successful projects, was on the lookout for new indie projects to help bring to life, and Abi was in a perfect place to hit the ground running.  It was a perfect match.

The team is completed with cinematographer, Jamison Acker, and production designer Colin Bach. Jamison works on Chicago PD in the camera department and has done several short films and features as a DP.  Colin has done prop mastering and production design on many feature films and various union shows in Chicago, including several of the One Chicago productions.

Tim has been making films since he saved his own money to buy a video camera in junior high.  A graduate of Columbia College, he’s worked as a filmmaker for all of his professional life.  

For the last four years, Tim has been pushing a dolly for the hit NBC television show Chicago PD. He never wastes an opportunity to apply the lessons he learns from working on larger sets to his own independent film-making. 

A committed nerd, Tim loves both the sci-fi and horror genres.  He was immediately drawn to Abi from the moment he read the first draft, and he has dedicated all of his energy to ensure the final film will be as amazing as the vision in his head.

Tim lives in Chicago with his exceedingly patient wife and crazy little monster Jack Russell terrier.

Dan has had a passion for visual storytelling since he first started experimenting with an old video camera as a child, and his excitement for the art of filmmaking has not calmed down since.

After graduating from Columbia College, Dan has spent the last decade working in film and television postproduction, editing programming for networks such as Discovery, History, A&E, Biography, and TLC.

Dan first developed the concept for Abi while attending college. Though the idea took a backseat to other projects for over a decade, he always knew he would return to his story about a mind-bending organic computer virus when the time was right. Now, he is thrilled to see his story brought to life by the most talented cast and crew he could ask for.

Dan lives in Chicago with his brilliant six-year-old daughter, who is a constant source of inspiration and also remarkably adept at keeping her father on course.

Ever since Corey can remember, he has wanted to make art and make movies.  He graduated from Illinois State University with a degree in Graphic Design and worked for several years as a professional designer in Chicago from 1994 to 2003.  

In 2003, Corey started his film and video production company, p3 mediaworks, with his brother. Still based in chiago, Corey has created many projects over the past 15 years both commercially and independently.  His work has appeared on television, in film festivals, and online platforms.

As soon as Tim handed Corey the script for Abi, he immediately fell in love with the concept and the story. He knew he needed to be a part of making the film a reality. He has worked tirelessly and put all of the resources available to p3 mediaworks toward that goal.

Clare Cooney: "Abi"

Clare is a Chicago-based theater, film, tv and commercial actor. A Detroit native, she moved to Chicago to pursue acting after graduating from The University of Notre Dame. Clare is a proud graduate of The School of Steppenwolf and has also worked with Chicago Dramatists, Northlight Theatre, Theater Wit, Redtwist Theatre, and the Backroom Shakespeare Project.

Clare received an award for Outstanding Acting at Sidewalk Film Festival in 2016 for her performance in the short film Bird of Prey. Her other recent film/TV credits include Hot Date on Pop TV, Shrink on NBC, Soul Sessions, directed by Vincent Gaffney, and Widows, directed by Steve McQueen and due for release in 2018.

Clare has enthusiastically dived into the bloody business of horror filmmaking with Abi. Her excitement for the project is evident in her performance, as she commits full throttle to the madness of the film's title character.

Clare is also a director and filmmaker. Her short film RUNNER recently World Premiered at Sidewalk Film Festival 2017, and won Best USA Short Film at Fairhope Film Festival 2017.

 

Rom Barkhordar: "Vincent"

Rom has been living and working as an actor in Chicago for nearly 20 years. His credits include Yasmina's Necklace for the Goodman Theatre, Uncle Vanya, or that's Life for Rasaka theatre, Mosque Alert for Silk Road Rising, and In a Garden for A Red Orchid theatre, which earned him a Jeff award nomination for best actor. 

Rom's regional credits include The Who and the What for the Huntington Theatre and Around the World in 80 days for Centerstage Baltimore and Kansas City Repertory Theatre. Television credits include Chicago Justice, Chicago Fire, Mind Games, Boss, and The Beast.  

Rom quickly became hooked on the visceral sci-fi psychological horror goodness crammed into Abi's twelve-page script. He cannot wait to start shooting with the determined and professional cast and crew. He knows it's going to be a blast.

Rom is currently preparing to play Amir in Ayad Akyar's pulitzer prize winning play, Disgraced, at Virginia Stage Company.

 

Emily Berman: "Julie"

Emily is a Chicago-based actor, musician, and voiceover artist, who was named one of the Chicago Tribune’s Hot New Faces in July of 2014. She grew up in the Chicago area, and is a proud graduate of Milwaukee Repertory Theatre's Emerging Residency Program and the University of Michigan, from which she holds a BFA in Acting and a BA in Economics.

Emily loves collaborating on new theatre work. Her Chicago credits include the roles of Tessa in the world premiere of Days Like Today at Writers Theatre, Lucy Steele in the world premiere of Sense and Sensibility at Chicago Shakespeare Theatre, and Mary Bennet in the world premiere of Miss Bennet: Christmas at Pemberly at Northlight Theatre.

Emily can't wait to work with "this top-notch team on such an exciting, unique, well-written script." Even just after one day of pre-production work, she is already sure that we're going to create something audiences will enjoy, and have a lot of fun doing it!

Emily works extensively in Chicago's voiceover scene. She has also played the roles of paramedic Jen Brenner on NBC's Chicago Fire and Ella Porter on Chicago PD.

 

Jennifer Goodman "Dispatcher"

Jennifer is an actress, screenwriter and director from the northern suburbs of Chicago, where she sits on several charity boards and focuses her energy on developing her craft in writing and acting.

Graduated from Ohio Wesleyan with a B.A in Theatre, Jennifer has grown her career focusing primarily on television and film. She's been seen in several commercials and films, including Commencement and The Break Up, and is recognized for her role as Katy Conrad in Conrad, a new crime/drama web series focusing on female empowerment, which Jennifer also writes.

Jennifer is thrilled to be a part of making Abi come to life. Calling it "a perfect dose of what society is facing today when it comes to computers taking over the industry," she feels lucky to be included with such a collaborative and creative group.

Jennifer currently owns Conrad Series, LLC with co-partners Ryan Atkins, and Jessica Lawson. She is currently hard at work on The Nest, a psychological thriller due to be released in 2018.

 

If You Can't Contribute

Maybe you want to join us, but can't back us right now.  That's fine!  There's still plenty you can do to help, and it's easy!  If you love sci-fi and horror as much as we do, you probably know a lot of people that would be interested in this film too.  Let them know it's out there!  Hit like and follow on this page, and share it out with your friends!

Maybe you're not convinced yet.  That's fine too!  Hit like on this page, and keep up to date as we release more about the film.  You can join us whenever you're ready!

Visit our FB page:  https://www.facebook.com/ShortFilmABI/
Follow us on Twitter:  @clmmovies


Thanks so much for checking us out and for supporting independent film!

story:
Short Summary

Hi, my name's Cristina, I'm the producer of this film. Me and Lana met at film course, we get along on this project defending LGBT rights because both of us come from Post-Soviet Union countries where the amount of homophobes is bigger than actual homosexuals. The paradoxical fact is that women always had the right to be lesbians, while male homosexuality was included in criminal code. Even when Soviet Union has fallen in 1991, and four years later was legalised homosexual activity they still don't have many rights, and they are not respected by the majority. 
There is a special word describing gays in Russian language 'pederasty' that is a derivation from word 'paedophile', meaning sexual activity involving a man and a boy. Scientifically, pederast and paedophile is a same thing, but in Soviet Union they put gay along with them. Being gay is a choice, while pederast or paedophilia is a crime. This wordplay leaded citizens to be disgusted of these minorities. 
When you think about Post Soviet Union countries is not a small group, territorial is half of the Eurasia; and it is consisting of 15 states: Russia, Armenia, Azerbaijan, Belarus, Estonia, Georgia, Kazakhstan, Kyrgyzstan, Latvia, Lithuania, Moldova, Tajikistan, Turkmenistan, Ukraine, Uzbekistan.

The major difference between soviet people from Western is that people are old-fashioned. Soviet Union was isolated from the rest of the world for 69 years (1922-1991), for the time when Soviet Union collapse, America already had LGBT films, people were used to it . Our goal, is to change retrospective view on LGBT society, and to show that this problem is still persisting. If in Western society they don't consider you for taking a job because you are homosexual or transgender, in Post Soviet Union countries you simply don't have a human rights. Some individuals may even bit someone to death because he or she is not "normal" in their point of view. It is a growing issue, people are treated disrespectful. Many of this people simply hide their identity, and decide to leave the country leading to another major problem as immigration. 
In a few years, would be people with no country and no name. Please, help us to solve this problem by simply contributing to our film; and if you do not have resources you still can help us by sharing the link. Let as many people you can know about our campaign. 

What We Need & What You Get

Our total budget is £3,320 considering the fact that we use a lot of university resources and we are not entirely paying our professional actors for their contribution. Any extra penny that we will get, we will share between actors. We were lucky enough to get professional actors from the Russian theatre in London. 
The money you contribute will go towards costs such as transport, catering, production design, entry fees for film festivals, music fees, and much more. Whether it's Pounds, Dollars, Euros, Hryvnia, Lei, Ruble, etc. we are grateful.


We are offering some wonderful perks alongside your donations, with rewards ranging from digital items such as early access to the completed film, to physical items such as exclusive production photobooks. We're also offering the chance for special producer credits for those more generous contributors. With levels starting from just £1, whatever your budget, there is a perfect perk to suit- the more you donate, the bigger your reward!
The main prize would be the person who donate most will be named Executive Producer, will be invited at the private film screening where you will meet actors and crew members, and I will make a gift from my own a painting representing "Rainbow flag", you can find it here https://www.artfinder.com/cristina-mihalachi#/q....

 

Other Ways You Can Help

Follow us on Facebook for more updates https://www.facebook.com/Bitterly-Sweet-Short-F...

story:
The Film

Incorporating elements of genre horror and art-house cinema with a heavy dose of conspiracy culture, the film is a must-see for fans of filmmakers like John Carpenter, David Lynch and Jim Jarmusch and for those of the Fortean persuasion. 

Bright Rectangle Films was founded by long-time creative partners Bill Darmon and Chris Ernst, who collectively bring over two decades of diverse experience in independent film and video production. We are taking the first steps towards creating a microstudio that makes the kind of movies that we feel audiences (like us) need today.

 

 

What We Need & What You Get

Principal photography and a rough cut are complete. We have already successfully captured most of our original script- and the edit runs approximately 70 minutes.  The film is very close to completion and only a bit more is needed- we're in the home stretch! We need funds to shoot additional VFX scenes and cover post-production costs like digital effects, music licensing, recording an original score, sound design and mixing, and color correction. 

Perks will include swag that feature original designs from the film- as well as original props and production materials that help see you beyond the veil of the production- and transport you to this twisted version of the haunted southwest, just like the finished movie eventually will. Blu-Rays, VHS, and downloadable media will be available in the Fall of 2019, after we hit the Festivals. All other items will be shipped out as soon as we can, with an estimate by the end of August 2018.

We'll also make the movie available in a VHS format- and its score available on cassette- because at its core, this movie is a product of the 80s and 90s. We'd like to think it's the kind of movie John Carpenter would have made given the same material (if written by the mutant child of Lawrence Kasdan, Dan O'Bannon, and Earl Mac Rauch). 

Funds raised over 30K will be used to make the film even better! Each and every contribution will help us get there. 

 

The Impact

Fritz Leiber, well known by many fans of classic genre and pulp literature, was an American writer of fantasy, horror, and science fiction. Alongside writers such as Robert E. Howard and Michael Moorcock, Leiber can be regarded as one of the fathers of sword and sorcery fantasy, having coined the term. An early writer of “Weird” fiction, he initiated a brief yet intense correspondence with H.P. Lovecraft, who "encouraged and influenced [Leiber's] literary development" before succumbing to his death. Beginning in the late 1950s, he was increasingly influenced by the works of Carl Jung, particularly by the concepts of the anima and the shadow. From the mid-1960s onwards, he began incorporating elements of Joseph Campbell's The Hero with a Thousand Faces. We were lucky to be able to work with Leiber’s estate and gain the rights to this fantastic story.

We expanded THATH to feature length in the spirit of Fritz Leiber's entire body of work.

To further that end- we shot THATH in a 2.66:1 aspect- a bit wider than 'scope- and if we're being honest, we'd prefer it show only in glorious CINERAMA- to really capture the spirit of the movie's unique locations in northeastern New Mexico and southeastern Colorado- eye-searing landscapes that rarely go up on the big screen.

We think we've got something new here- born from a genre crucible like none other.

 

Risks & Challenges

Principal photography and a rough cut are done. The film is very close to completion and only a bit more is needed to push the film over the finish line. To get this done we need funds to shoot additional VFX scenes and cover post-production costs like digital effects, music licensing, recording an original score, sound design and mixing, and color correction. With your help we will easily be able to fund these finishing phases of the production. Help get us over the finish line!

Other Ways You Can Help

A contribution is not only cashola! Please share the trailer and our fundraising here. Those efforts will help tremendously.
story_txt:
The Film
Incorporating elements of genre horror and art-house cinema with a heavy dose of conspiracy culture, the film is a must-see for fans of filmmakers like John Carpenter, David Lynch and Jim Jarmusch and for those of the Fortean persuasion. 
Bright Rectangle Films was founded by long-time creative partners Bill Darmon and Chris Ernst, who collectively bring over two decades of diverse experience in independent film and video production. We are taking the first steps towards creating a microstudio that makes the kind of movies that we feel audiences (like us) need today.
 




 
What We Need & What You Get
Principal photography and a rough cut are complete. We have already successfully captured most of our original script- and the edit runs approximately 70 minutes.  The film is very close to completion and only a bit more is needed- we're in the home stretch! We need funds to shoot additional VFX scenes and cover post-production costs like digital effects, music licensing, recording an original score, sound design and mixing, and color correction. 
Perks will include swag that feature original designs from the film- as well as original props and production materials that help see you beyond the veil of the production- and transport you to this twisted version of the haunted southwest, just like the finished movie eventually will. Blu-Rays, VHS, and downloadable media will be available in the Fall of 2019, after we hit the Festivals. All other items will be shipped out as soon as we can, with an estimate by the end of August 2018.
We'll also make the movie available in a VHS format- and its score available on cassette- because at its core, this movie is a product of the 80s and 90s. We'd like to think it's the kind of movie John Carpenter would have made given the same material (if written by the mutant child of Lawrence Kasdan, Dan O'Bannon, and Earl Mac Rauch). 
Funds raised over 30K will be used to make the film even better! Each and every contribution will help us get there. 




 
The Impact
Fritz Leiber, well known by many fans of classic genre and pulp literature, was an American writer of fantasy, horror, and science fiction. Alongside writers such as Robert E. Howard and Michael Moorcock, Leiber can be regarded as one of the fathers of sword and sorcery fantasy, having coined the term. An early writer of “Weird” fiction, he initiated a brief yet intense correspondence with H.P. Lovecraft, who "encouraged and influenced [Leiber's] literary development" before succumbing to his death. Beginning in the late 1950s, he was increasingly influenced by the works of Carl Jung, particularly by the concepts of the anima and the shadow. From the mid-1960s onwards, he began incorporating elements of Joseph Campbell's The Hero with a Thousand Faces. We were lucky to be able to work with Leiber’s estate and gain the rights to this fantastic story.
We expanded THATH to feature length in the spirit of Fritz Leiber's entire body of work.
To further that end- we shot THATH in a 2.66:1 aspect- a bit wider than 'scope- and if we're being honest, we'd prefer it show only in glorious CINERAMA- to really capture the spirit of the movie's unique locations in northeastern New Mexico and southeastern Colorado- eye-searing landscapes that rarely go up on the big screen.

We think we've got something new here- born from a genre crucible like none other.



 
Risks & Challenges
Principal photography and a rough cut are done. The film is very close to completion and only a bit more is needed to push the film over the finish line. To get this done we need funds to shoot additional VFX scenes and cover post-production costs like digital effects, music licensing, recording an original score, sound design and mixing, and color correction. With your help we will easily be able to fund these finishing phases of the production. Help get us over the finish line!



Other Ways You Can Help
A contribution is not only cashola! Please share the trailer and our fundraising here. Those efforts will help tremendously.

story:
In a Nut Shell.

Hey! Thanks for checking out our campaign. My name is Arwen Hawley-Brandt, I am a 23-year-old filmmaker from Devon, studying in my final year of Film at Falmouth University in Cornwall. I am also the writer, director, producer and editor for Pulse. I have a vast range of experience within both filmmaking and editing, and pride myself on the quality of my work. 

Pulse is my dissertation film for my final year at University; not only is it hugely important in terms of my degree, but also within my future career opportunities. This film will help me convey to future employers my abilities and creativity within this field of filmmaking, and can assist me within my career prospects in the future. 

Not only will Pulse assist me within my filmmaking future, it is also an opportunity for local creatives and artists to work together within a inspiring environment, to expand within their own field of work. The film is split into 20 individual scenes, each a film within itself, all to be edited together into a beautiful mess of visual empowerment and powerful images.

We are filming throughout March when the weather gets better, and shall have the film completed (hopefully) by April, ready to be sent to film festivals around the world. The end result shall not only be an amazing 10 minute film, but also an exhibition-fundraiser to raise money for a charity helping those with addiction issues. 

So, please, have a look at the rest of our plans, the people who are working on the production, and see if this interests you. Thank you so much. Arwen. 


The Story and Plan.

Pulse is a ten minute experimental film, evolving around a hallucinogenic drug trip; the movie begins as a beautiful and fairy-tale like journey, but quickly sours and spirals into a living hell. Rather than having the main character physically being in each scene with the audience witnessing her ordeal through reactions and actions, we are instead seeing her experience directly through her eyes, as she is living it.

As a result, we are planning to create 20 individual scenes, each one revolved around separate and evolving colour, theme and style. Pulse is also a unique production, as we are having local artists and creators within both Devon and Cornwall collaborate within many scenes, including carpenters, special effects artists, and florists.
This is a winner for all, in the sense it gives the creators a platform and opportunity to be as creative as they wish and excel within their art form, but also help make Pulse a more unique and enticing visual experience for the audience.

Below is the timeline and reflecting colour chart for 'Pulse', showcasing the development of context compared to the colouring for when I'm editing. 



Pre-Production Work.

Much research has gone into the creation of Pulse; watching films containing drug trips as well as old age experimental films encouraged the creative process, as did conducting surveys of those who have experienced visual drug trips. Studying these films and their different creative aspects ensured I styled my own scenes around originality and creative development within my writing and design for Pulse. 



During my research I conducted a survey, asking people who had taken hallucinogenic drugs what they had seen and experienced; the results have helped my vastly within the development of creating this piece . . . 

'On ecstacy once I saw purple beards on women, also children skipping down the pavements of deserted streets in the early morning and also saw victorianwoman pushing a large victoriana pram across a road in front of our vehicle'

'Looked like trees were waving at me in the wind and it’s like everything was those fibre optic lights and I would just seen colour changing light everywhere'

'Took a pill I’d never taken before. I started to feel awful so went to bed when we got home. The outlines of objects in the room changed into threatening things (a backpack on a chair was a massive gorilla, a dressing gown hanging off the wardrobe was a girl with no head. Etc) so I went outside to try and clear my head, I sat down and I was sat on the floor of the club with the flashing lights and people around me, I couldn’t shake the image it was really scary. I can’t remember what happened from there but it put me off pills for life'

'I saw a dark shadow standing at the end of my bed, he was just standing there; he then began to pull my covers off my body for what felt like hours, me tugging against his pulls' 

'...Ketamine however was a very different experience.. That made me lose all control of my legs and convinced me that the floor was definitely lava and so I couldn't get off the sofa'

Some of these statements have been used as a spring board within the imagery and narratives that will occur within Pulse. 
____________________

Production Design 

The production design has been heavily influence by the work of Anya Antia and Nicolas Bruno, both creative photographers; Anya uses extremely beautiful imagery within her work, mostly working with female models and animals, creating fairytale like photographs with the usage of props, lighting and costumes. For the first half of Pulse, much of my designs have been heavily influenced by her creations. 



https://anya-anti.com

Nicolas Bruno is also a photographer, who creates photos re-creating his night-terrors; strong, dark images obtain his work and holds a hellish-feel within the photos. The second half of Pulse has been hugely influenced by his style and beautiful creations. 



http://www.nicolasbrunophotography.com 

The imagery within Pulse shall be much like watching a Lucid Dream; inspired by these music videos, as well as the visual and audio work of Grimes, Clams Casino, Lorn, Apex Twin, Gotye, M83, The Smashing Pumpkins, Kate Bush, Fever Ray, The Avalanches, Marilyn Manson, Die Antwoord and more, the images obtain within these creations shall hold strong stance within Pulse. 

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=oEeNUnMaAf8

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=C_QsPuKtI3M

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=wokbmH1iGtU

The above links are strong examples of the atmosphere and imagery we aim to create. 

Throughout pre-production, much work and effort has gone into the production designs and aesthetical aims of Pulse; mood boards, storyboards, character design and costume ideas and plans have evolved and changed to a point of successful accomplishment in the prep for the film.






Painting, writing, costumes and props have been created, bought and planned, ready for the next coming months; 
 



Writing over 20 individual scenes is hard work, but each is designed and is catering for whoever is specialising within that scene and helping the character development within the film.



Along with the script, detailed storyboards have been designed alongside them, to ensure prep and filming each scene will go as smoothly and accurately as possible.

The start of a scene design. 


Filming. 

We are filming the majority of Pulse in March, giving us enough time for any re-needed reshoots and plenty of time for the editing and animation to bring the story together properly.

We have been lucky enough to secure some amazing locations to film Pulse within, including Dartmoor National Park, Totnes, Denbury and Moonridge Farm; 



___________________________________________________________________





The Team 

Pulse is a film being created and designed by local people in Devon and Cornwall, contributing their artistic skills for the film; I have an incredible batch of people from all walks of life contributing their time, effort and talents towards this production. Its excessively humbling and exciting to see.

Arwen Hawley-Brandt 
Director, Producer, Writer, Editor. 



Hi, I’m Arwen and I am the Writer, Producer, Director and Editor for ‘Pulse’. I am in my final year at Falmouth University, studying film, and ‘Pulse’ is my dissertation project. I have vast experience within the industry, having set up my own production company and worked professionally also. My clients have included Devon County Council and The National Trust. I love filmmaking and am very excited about working on Pulse and bringing it to life, not only as my dissertation piece for University, but as the start of my creative career within film.  
Please, check out my personal showreel, all of which is filmed and edited by myself; 

 

 


Mauro Colareiti.
Cinematographer.


Hey, I’m Mauro. Don’t even try to say it because you’re probably saying it wrong. I’m an Italian second year Film student at Falmouth University, specialising in screenwriting but with experience as a cinematographer. I have a background in publishing books and being a contributing writer for magazines, but the most important thing to me is storytelling, so I’m pretty open to everything that involves characters and plots.

Stephanie Gaynard.
Sound Designer.

Hey I'm Steph, I'm a second year film student at Falmouth university. I'm specialising in Sound Design but I love post production including editing. I have worked in both fields and enjoy them both the same. I have a background with working with films and animation. I enjoy piecing the story together through post production as it's a very rewarding role


Creative Contributors; 

Actors: 

During the production, we are going to have several actors and actress' involved within all the shoots; 
________________________________________________



From professionals, to students, to family, all these people involved are brilliant and talented in all kinds of ways. Having been told the kind of film we are creating, they are all excited and looking forward to the process involved within creating this production! 


Zoe Leonard / Perks 
Music 


Perks is the latest source of vitality to the trip-hop scene bringing grandeuristic, emotional power to the forefront. Her haunting yet beautiful production sees it's influences rooted in artists like Bonobo and Cinematic Orchestra. Described as an "ambient trip-hop delight" and "exceptionally pretty... believably emotional" Perks takes on a new endeavour for Pulse. Drawing inspiration from Clams Casino, LORN, and Andy Stott, Perks' dark yet subtle soundscape will showcase the shadowy struggle and evocative beauty compiled within Pulse.

https://soundcloud.com/iamperks

Ash Linton.
Makeup and Special Effects.


Hi, I’m Ash and my company's name is "AtrophyFX". I’m a self-taught fx artist hailing out of Plymouth, specialising in prosthetic makeup and props creation. I've worked in the local independent film scene for roughly 5 years creating a number of weird and wonderful makeups. Most recently I assisted a makeup at IMATS with the garner brothers on their lizard warrior, where I designed the weapon and arm appliances and helped apply. With a few more projects in the pipeline I’m always busy when I least expect it! Which is why I love what I do, exploring the unknown and the chance of creating something brand new.



https://www.instagram.com/atrophyfx_/

Amy Gilbert 
Florist 


Hi, my name is Amy Gilbert of The Flower Forest; I grow my own seasonal flowers, grasses and foliage and anything else that catches my eye, to create very natural arrangements with the aim of captivating the senses through colour, texture and scent. I like to use lots of wild foraged elements in my work, inspired by nature and the seasons.



https://www.flowersfromthefarm.co.uk

Milena Watts 
Body Makeup Artist 


Hi, I’m Milena, and I’m a self taught makeup artist with four years of learning under my belt. I have been interested in makeup for forever and take any excuse to make a new character. I decided to make an instagram account called Milenasmakeups to show an online portfolio of my work and after reaching 1000 followers I made a youtube to show tutorials on how to create my creatures. Since putting my self out there on the web I’ve been given great job opportunities, such as working on the set of a local film and working with Crealy Adventure Park over halloween as a makeup artist for the scare actors. I’ve also recently won first place for this years Devon body art exhibition which was a great way for me to connect and learn more about makeup through other artists. The fact that I can create a piece of art on a living canvas is one of my favorite things about body art because it can bring your paintings to life!



https://www.instagram.com/milenasmakeups

Rowan Stickland
Carpentry


Hi, I'm Rowan Stickland and I'm a creative carpenter based in Totnes Devon; I design and build Pods, low impact living spaces inspired by nature but designed to withstand our wild weather. With a background in cabinet making, greenwoodwork and yurt building, I custom make all season shelters for those who require quality structures for all conditions that also look beautiful in their surroundings. As well as Pods and Polytunnels I also turn my hand to a number of other projects in wood, anything from tableware to tables or cabinets to candlesticks.



http://www.rowanstickland.co.uk

Jane Brandt
Costume Designer


Having started and run a theatre company specialising in Shakespearean production for the past 16 years I have to work on a number of skill sets from acting and directing to publicity, stage management, producing the programme etc etc etc - the list is endless but I've always had a particular interest in Costumes - designing, making and hiring.We generally produce fairly classical Shakespearean productions with doublets and hose galore, but sometimes there's the need to be more creative such as with the Faerie costumes for A Midsummer Night's dream and Prospero's magical cloak in The Tempest. After 16 years we've built up a good selection of slightly off the wallcostumes using especially fine materials which catch the light on stage and produce magical effects. This year's plan is again the Dream and we're not going for floaty pretty faeries but evil sprite like characters, challenging my design skills yet again.Costumes can make or break a production and are very powerful in helping the actors find their characters, often being the starting point for giving the entire mood and feel to a production and when it comes to theperformance it gives me great pride that I've had such an important role in making it successful.



http://www.theinntheatrecompany.co.uk

Ellie Lorna Carter 
Solo Pilot


Hi, I'm Ellie and I am the UKs youngest solo pilot at 15 years old, and have been for a year.  I fly gliders, WW2 aircraft and have some sponsorship from Virgin galactic, and have been  on Breakfast T.V, Spotlight, London radio, sky news etc. as a result. I am looking forward to working on Pulse. 



http://www.northdevongazette.co.uk/news/torring...


Throughout the next couple of months, I shall continue recruiting and getting other creative people on board;


Festivals.
Once the film is completed I plan on entering Pulse into a range of festivals around the world, hoping to showcase our work to a large group of people. Some of those include . . . 

•Short Cut  NYC International Cinemafest

•Big Sur International Short Film Festival

•Screamfest Horror Film Festival

•World Arts Film Festival

•Cinemafantastique 4

•NCCC Film & Animation Festival

•Universal Film Festival

•Raindance

•Encounters Festival 



Exhibition. 
Due to the subject of Pulse, I felt there was a real opportunity here to give something back; 
I want Pulse to not only showcase a seriously dark drug trip, but to also represent the journey drug abusers often entail, with their addiction beginning as an amazing aspect to their life, before it quickly spirals into a living hell. As a result, we are holding the premiere, an exhibition and a fundraiser all in one in the summer, to not only open the film to the world, but to also showcase the talent of those involved, all whilst raising money for a charity helping those with addictions. 
We have a charity who have agreed to be involved, but only once they have seen the finished product, due to the context. 

The Exhibition will give all the artists, musicians, creators and people involved  within the production to show their work, their abilities, and to also give them an opportunity to gain more work through this event. Each shall have their own table to show and discuss their creative history, their contribution to the film, their process and future ambitions to the visitors of the event. 


Funding.

Any help given financially to create this piece will be hugely appreciated in so many ways; it'll result in me being able to produce a film of higher quality, creativity and will grant me the chance to fully show my capabilities within this region of artistry. 

The money is needed for a range of reasons; we want to create the most high-quality film possible, and unfortunately, this takes both time and money. Props, makeup, sources, travel expenses and everything in-between add up quickly. We have, however, planned and budgeted a basic sum of £2,200 to cover travel, crew, food, costumes and makeup, festival entry fees and to organize our Exhibition piece.

Please note, I am wanting to pay people within the production for their materials used, and also their time; you can't buy bread or pay your rent with 'exposure', so why not have both? I, however, obviously, will not be getting any money personally from my work on the production. 


Being a student film, and also wanting to pay people for their times and talents, every penny is going towards not only the creation of ‘Pulse’, but also financial recognition of peoples combined and individual efforts within the production.

If we do not reach our entire goal, the money will be spent in the most practical ways, towards both the production and with the crew; props are a key aspect within our production, just as much as it is supplying our crew with the tools they need to create and do what they have to do.  As a result, the money will be budgeted to the best way we can manage.

Overall, this film is not just a film to any of the crew; it’s an opportunity to be expressive creatively and artistically. Its giving people who are passionate and talented within their fields a rare chance to express themselves and create things that would otherwise not see the light of day. It will give me and them both the platform to expand their portfolio in a positive sense, and open opportunity’s for our creative future.
 


Risks & Challenges
Like anything to do with film,  creativity and life in general - Nothing goes according to plan. Things mess up, plans a scuppered, the weather lets you down and so do people. However, with Pulse having such a variety of people, places and narratives involved, even if 50% went wrong (which it won't!) I will still possess enough footage to create an equally unique, beautiful and enticing film. Its gonna be good! :) 

 

Other Ways You Can Help
If you aren't in a position to donate, if you could please spread the word, share it with your family and friends and help us drum up interest, we would all be so grateful. This is an awesome opportunity for all of us involved and we want to create something truly unique and exciting. 
Thank you so much, from all of us! 


Thank you so much in advance for your help and contribution. 
Arwen Hawley-Brandt

I like to use lots of wild foraged elements in my work, inspired by nature and the seasons.
https://www.flowersfromthefarm.co.ukMilena Watts Body Makeup Artist Hi, I’m Milena, and I’m a self taught makeup artist with four years of learning under my belt. I have been interested in makeup for forever and take any excuse to make a new character. I decided to make an instagram account called Milenasmakeups to show an online portfolio of my work and after reaching 1000 followers I made a youtube to show tutorials on how to create my creatures. Since putting my self out there on the web I’ve been given great job opportunities, such as working on the set of a local film and working with Crealy Adventure Park over halloween as a makeup artist for the scare actors. I’ve also recently won first place for this years Devon body art exhibition which was a great way for me to connect and learn more about makeup through other artists. The fact that I can create a piece of art on a living canvas is one of my favorite things about body art because it can bring your paintings to life!https://www.instagram.com/milenasmakeupsRowan SticklandCarpentryHi, I'm Rowan Stickland and I'm a creative carpenter based in Totnes Devon; I design and build Pods, low impact living spaces inspired by nature but designed to withstand our wild weather. With a background in cabinet making, greenwoodwork and yurt building, I custom make all season shelters for those who require quality structures for all conditions that also look beautiful in their surroundings. As well as Pods and Polytunnels I also turn my hand to a number of other projects in wood, anything from tableware to tables or cabinets to candlesticks.http://www.rowanstickland.co.ukJane BrandtCostume DesignerHaving started and run a theatre company specialising in Shakespearean production for the past 16 years I have to work on a number of skill sets from acting and directing to publicity, stage management, producing the programme etc etc etc - the list is endless but I've always had a particular interest in Costumes - designing, making and hiring.We generally produce fairly classical Shakespearean productions with doublets and hose galore, but sometimes there's the need to be more creative such as with the Faerie costumes for A Midsummer Night's dream and Prospero's magical cloak in The Tempest. After 16 years we've built up a good selection of slightly off the wallcostumes using especially fine materials which catch the light on stage and produce magical effects. This year's plan is again the Dream and we're not going for floaty pretty faeries but evil sprite like characters, challenging my design skills yet again.Costumes can make or break a production and are very powerful in helping the actors find their characters, often being the starting point for giving the entire mood and feel to a production and when it comes to theperformance it gives me great pride that I've had such an important role in making it successful.http://www.theinntheatrecompany.co.ukEllie Lorna Carter Solo PilotHi, I'm Ellie and I am the UKs youngest solo pilot at 15 years old, and have been for a year.  I fly gliders, WW2 aircraft and have some sponsorship from Virgin galactic, and have been  on Breakfast T.V, Spotlight, London radio, sky news etc. as a result. I am looking forward to working on Pulse. http://www.northdevongazette.co.uk/news/torring...Throughout the next couple of months, I shall continue recruiting and getting other creative people on board;Festivals.Once the film is completed I plan on entering Pulse into a range of festivals around the world, hoping to showcase our work to a large group of people. Some of those include . . . •Short Cut  NYC International Cinemafest
•Big Sur International Short Film Festival
•Screamfest Horror Film Festival
•World Arts Film Festival
•Cinemafantastique 4
•NCCC Film & Animation Festival
•Universal Film Festival
•Raindance
•Encounters Festival 
Exhibition. Due to the subject of Pulse, I felt there was a real opportunity here to give something back; I want Pulse to not only showcase a seriously dark drug trip, but to also represent the journey drug abusers often entail, with their addiction beginning as an amazing aspect to their life, before it quickly spirals into a living hell. As a result, we are holding the premiere, an exhibition and a fundraiser all in one in the summer, to not only open the film to the world, but to also showcase the talent of those involved, all whilst raising money for a charity helping those with addictions. We have a charity who have agreed to be involved, but only once they have seen the finished product, due to the context. The Exhibition will give all the artists, musicians, creators and people involved  within the production to show their work, their abilities, and to also give them an opportunity to gain more work through this event. Each shall have their own table to show and discuss their creative history, their contribution to the film, their process and future ambitions to the visitors of the event. Funding.
Any help given financially to create this piece will be hugely appreciated in so many ways; it'll result in me being able to produce a film of higher quality, creativity and will grant me the chance to fully show my capabilities within this region of artistry. The money is needed for a range of reasons; we want to create the most high-quality film possible, and unfortunately, this takes both time and money. Props, makeup, sources, travel expenses and everything in-between add up quickly. We have, however, planned and budgeted a basic sum of £2,200 to cover travel, crew, food, costumes and makeup, festival entry fees and to organize our Exhibition piece.Please note, I am wanting to pay people within the production for their materials used, and also their time; you can't buy bread or pay your rent with 'exposure', so why not have both? I, however, obviously, will not be getting any money personally from my work on the production. 

Being a student film, and also wanting to pay people for their times and talents, every penny is going towards not only the creation of ‘Pulse’, but also financial recognition of peoples combined and individual efforts within the production.If we do not reach our entire goal, the money will be spent in the most practical ways, towards both the production and with the crew; props are a key aspect within our production, just as much as it is supplying our crew with the tools they need to create and do what they have to do.  As a result, the money will be budgeted to the best way we can manage.
Overall, this film is not just a film to any of the crew; it’s an opportunity to be expressive creatively and artistically. Its giving people who are passionate and talented within their fields a rare chance to express themselves and create things that would otherwise not see the light of day. It will give me and them both the platform to expand their portfolio in a positive sense, and open opportunity’s for our creative future. 
Risks & ChallengesLike anything to do with film,  creativity and life in general - Nothing goes according to plan. Things mess up, plans a scuppered, the weather lets you down and so do people. However, with Pulse having such a variety of people, places and narratives involved, even if 50% went wrong (which it won't!) I will still possess enough footage to create an equally unique, beautiful and enticing film. Its gonna be good! :)  
Other Ways You Can HelpIf you aren't in a position to donate, if you could please spread the word, share it with your family and friends and help us drum up interest, we would all be so grateful. This is an awesome opportunity for all of us involved and we want to create something truly unique and exciting. Thank you so much, from all of us! Thank you so much in advance for your help and contribution. Arwen Hawley-Brandt

story:
Hi! 

We are a collective of artists looking to fund our short film, "7ft, Hairy and Handsome", an animated horror-comedy. 

After lying to his blind date about his appearance, an anxious young man attempts to make a dramatic change to his body by being bitten by a Werewolf.

About the story -

The transitioning /transforming body in horror is frequently presented as the monstrous other. They are either psychopathic, murderous characters or the actual act of transitioning is depicted as violent, gory and self harming and leaves the character grappling with their humanity.  This story re-imagines these tropes.

The story turns the mirror onto the part of society that sees transitioning bodies as monstrous and grotesque. It is a story about self confidence and self belief, addressing anyone who feels discomfort with their own body as well as being a story about the horror of toxic masculinity.

While the themes and places I have drawn inspiration from this film are very important and, I want to present the film in a comical, fun way. In a time in our society where there is a lot of scaremongering around LGBT issues it is important to me to create a fun queer horror film, where the protagonist's sexuality is not a main plot point.

The film will be presented as a highly stylised CGI animation, drawing animation style from bold classic cartoons and combining this with hand painted textures. Taking mood and atmosphere cues from the horror genre and slapstick, caricatured comedy we are creating something that I haven't seen before in animation. 

About us - 

In university I was lucky enough to work with an amazing team of creatives on our final student film (available here! - https://vimeo.com/271063108), something we are all really proud of and went on to be screened at a bunch of festivals which was really cool! We enjoyed working together so much we decided to collaborate again on this film and have further future plans to start our own studio.

Since making our student film, our team members have been studying masters courses, training courses at Aardman Animations and working in professional positions in animation companies all over the country on some amazing projects such as Netflix's 'Happy!' and the new 'Dark Crystal: Age of Resistance'. We have all learned so much since graduating and believe we can really make a film that is unique and engaging.

Production -

7ft, Hairy and Handsome was shortlisted for the Scottish Film Talent Network's short film programme. Although we unfortunately weren't selected as a final film for commission we attended a series of script development workshops, helping us to create, what we believe is a really strong screenplay.

The film will be completed over the next year as part of the artist residency at Duncan of Jordanstone College of Art and Design. Most of the pre production work for the film has been completed and we are getting ready to move into production!

Where Your Money Goes -

Animation takes a long time and is expensive!

We would really love to be able to pay the amazing artists that we are lucky enough to have had contribute to this film so far, as well as employing artists to help with the work our immediate team isn't able to do (modelling, rigging, texturing). We also hope to have an original score composed as well as hiring voice actors and a sound mixer. 

If we make enough money some of the money will also go to entry to promotion of the film and entry to festivals.

Characters & Concepts -

 

Artwork by Fiona Burton (www.fionaburton.com) and Amanda McGovern (www.amandamcgovern.co.uk)

 

Thank You

so much for taking the time to read, I appreciate any amount of money you are able to contribute SO much, and if you aren't able to pay sharing this page would be wonderful also !

story:
Who Are You?

We are a team of award-winning young filmmakers working under the yellow WillCarne Pictures banner, led by producers Rebecca Winkler, Annie Hopkins and Tom Dimech. This will be the second feature from writer/director Will following Dear Will Carne (2019), a heartwarming discussion about mental health. LOVE WILL is our most ambitious project to date, forming a collaboration of 40 independent creatives from across London.

Find out more about individual members below...

 

 

Why Crowdfund?

So far we've self-funded £5,478 (and 18p) filming half of the 80 minute film. We need to raise a further £3000 to complete the film, and crowdfunding seemed the perfect solution, so we can involve as many people as possible and give an insight into the behind-the-scenes of making a project like this. Our stretch goal (£8000) will allow us to have some more ambitious locations and sequences in the film, and enable us to record the soundtrack with a live band.

 

 

What Do I Get?

As a backer, we're inviting you to experience the process of making a musical film, without the hard work of actually doing it (we've got that covered!) Backers can follow the project step-by-step on IndieGoGo via access to an exclusive series that we are calling The Coming Out Story. With interviews with the cast and crew, spotlights on the filmmaking process, and clips and outtakes from set.

For the full list of all the perks available, check out the sidebar.

 

Why are you making this film?

We're all for putting the story first, so ultimately we're making this film because we want to tell this story. Over time, the project has grown bigger and bigger, as more people have joined the team and given their time to tell a coming out story, a new original musical, and a feature length rom-com all rolled into one. For many of the actors and crew members this will be the next big step in their careers, and for some their first feature film.

 

 

The Story

Will is starting a new job in a theatre London's West End with his best friend Amy (Amy Lovatt), who offers her own unique form of comfort following the end of Will's relationship with his ex-girlfriend (Sapphire Stutchbury). On the first day of rehearsals Will stumbles into someone that will change his life forever: Harry (David Fallon, Aiden Felgate, Jason Patel, George Jennings and Meg Jobling). As romance begins to blossom we delve into Will's past, as he discovers how to open up through music and dance. Think of the following ten songs as ten clues to what happens in the movie...

  1. Neverland in My Head
  2. (Shh! This one's a secret...)
  3. Dance of the DMs
  4. I Think I'm Falling in Love
  5. Neverland in My Head (Reprise)
  6. One Small Step
  7. The Angry Tap Dance
  8. Come Out Again
  9. (Shh! This one's a secret...)
  10. Love Will

GENRE: Romance / Comedy / Musical / Coming of Age / British

THEMES: LGBT+ / Mental health / Theatre / Love / Imagination

 

 

Meet the Team

THE CAST

"WILL" - Will Carne - known for Dear Will Carne, Will trained in tap for nine months for a single tap dance sequence in the film. He describes the character of Will as "loosely based on himself, but far more interesting".

"YOUNG WILL" - Louis Parker - this will be Louis' first feature, after stunning the producers in his audition with his tap skills and beautiful singing voice.

"AMY" - Amy Lovatt - best known for her musical theatre YouTube channel, this will be Amy's first feature film appearance.

The full cast have been announced on our IMdB page: https://www.imdb.com/title/tt10526570.

 

THE CREW

Rebecca Winkler - Ravensbourne graduate producer and award-winning director of Hostages.

Annie Hopkins - Ravensbourne film graduate. Award-winning director of Noah’s Wish. Mother of two.

Tom Dimech - Casual theatre producer, product manager and general great guy.

Will Carne - Ravensbourne film graduate, freelance creative producer and fan of yellow.

Alex Newell - Director of Photography, Citreon C1 owner and beard enthusiast.

Cillian Donaghy - Musical Director, tenor, harpist and master of key changes.

Kimberly Bradford - expert in digital marketing and brand strategy, shih tzu owner and our token American.

story:
"I'm hearing voices in my head and I can't take it anymore" how would you react if your friend came up to you seeking help? or during their episode, people distance themselves instead getting closer to a solution.

My name is June Mugo, I am a young filmmaker from Jersey City, New Jersey. I moved to Maryland after I graduated from college. During my undergrad, I studied Sociology and Psychology because I knew one day, I wanted to educate people. I have a sharp eye for creativity, and captivating people's interest in what I am showcasing. 

During my time in school, two of my closest friends had schizophrenia, and you can see people did not understand and feared the truth of understanding what was happening. Four years later, I got the urge to write about it. Not their stories in particular but the rest of the people around the world who have been silenced by their mental disorder.

This campaign will help bring these stories to life and educate people. Many people believe they have to step into a class and learn or experience it themselves. But my film will give the feeling of "wow, how can I learn more?" This campaign will give the opportunity of allowing this project to spread its wings into more hands and capture a remarkable motion picture.

Unfortunately, it costs to deliver such a invaluable message. I have invested in myself and would be highly appreciative to receive help because it is not easy! Camera gear and the right people to make this great are not cheap, but you want the project to be great so of course it can't be cheap!

The total cost is $15,000. This covers the best equipment, the valuable team members passionate about the topic, donation to food donors, place to stay, food, and the actors.

The ultimate goal is to submit this project to some of the best film festivals (nationally and internationally) and distributors known today, which will result in about thousands maybe millions of viewers. Having your name on the big screen as a contributor would be breathtaking! Contributing to such a beautiful project, possibly going to some of the festivals! But in order to win and get the film into festivals, it has to have a compelling story (which I have) and has to be visually appealing. Some distributors require certain cameras to be used. These cameras cost between $500-$5000 to rent. But the end result is invaluable! Your favorite film was shot in these cameras!

My last film was low budget but I made the best of it. I was able to bring in the best people to do the project, great mentors and it made it into a couple festivals. With a bigger budget people will be motivated to help the project, the right equipment can be used and it will qualify to be in the top festivals and distributing companies around the world.

After my first project I learned I was not missing the right actors or camera people, it was the funding. Although I was able to figure it out by using cheaper gear, this time I want to go above and beyond. I have learned lessons, took classes and I am ready to make this project worth the investment.

 

Please contribute to the great cause, tell your friends and use the Indiegogo share tools to spread the word. A thank you isn't enough but I will say a great end result will make you feel proud.

 

Thank you,

 

June Mugo

story:
What would happen if the government ordered all of the nation’s incarcerated prisoners to retreat to an island to live amongst each other and fend for themselves? Citizens may support this change as these criminals are seen as problematic and forgettable. Oasis of the Mind tells the story of a curious guard’s journey rediscovering the humanity that was lost in these prisoners. Our film will tell this story of a theoretical future for our world. 

In Oasis of the Mind, a law is passed that casts citizens, known as “Deplorables,” out to a deserted Island in an attempt to maintain order within their society, known as “The Nation.” When a new guard, Danni, is stationed on the island, she soon notices abnormal behavior amongst the Deplorables. This inspires her to look deeper into the Deplorables and their way of living. She does this through developing a relationship with one female prisoner in particular, named Armina. By observing Armina’s tribe on the Island, Danni learns the truth behind The Nation's blinded morality. Through this newfound awareness, she becomes more empathetic and considerate towards the Deplorables. Danni begins to see the Deplorables as her equals.

Through Oasis of the Mind, we want to shed light on the misconceptions of the prison system. Our team hopes to communicate to our audience that some incarcerated individuals are able to heal from the world’s mistakes. These individuals deserve to be treated as humans, not just as an embodiment of their past mistakes.

This film also explores the instinctive sense of purpose found when humans are placed in a primitive state of living- exemplifying our connection to nature. Living in the wild presents many challenges and creates possibilities for people to help one another survive and in turn creating a community. Reprioritizing one’s mind to focus on surviving first and foremost can open many doors to healing as a result. 

 

Oasis of the Mind is our senior capstone project that will cumulatively embody the talent, professionalism, and dedication of our entire cast and crew. It has been a productive four-year journey here at SCAD and we are bursting at the seams with excitement to bring Oasis of the Mind into production to share with you. In order to do so, we need your help! 

Fundraising will go directly towards each department of our film to fund things like props, costumes, location fees, transportation, and equipment. Our  project is very heavily depending on the support of our friends, family, and maybe some people we haven’t even met yet. 

We have some really neat incentives we will be distributing to our supporters as a token of our gratitude. You can check them out on the right side of this campaign page!

Every contribution from our supporters will bring us closer to reaching our goal. A little bit goes a long way in student filmmaking. Even sharing our campaign with your family and friends will bring additional traffic to our page, so go ahead and copy our link below and post it to your accounts!

There are several ways for you to help!

FOLLOW along with our journey on Instagram https://www.instagram.com/_oasisofthemind_/  

Join the oasis and CONTRIBUTE to our campaign https://www.indiegogo.com/projects/oasis-of-the... 

SHARE our campaign with your friends and family on social media https://www.indiegogo.com/projects/oasis-of-the...

Thank you in advance for all of your help and for supporting our dream! We absolutely could not do this without you!

 

The smoking hot graphic below depicts the percentages of our total funding that will be distributed to each department on our team. Breakdowns of specific departments’ needs can also be found below.

Art Department and Construction - 40%

The art department is a huge part of Oasis of the Mind! Our amazing production designer, Tierney Brennan, has done her very best to deliver the vision that Eryn has brought forwards. This part of the budget will be going towards costuming and set construction for the film. 

Set Operations - 22%

Filming select scenes will require police and firemen supervision. Part of the set operations funding will go towards paying these members of our community who generously take the time to help us out!

Food - 20%

One of our filming days, we will be feeding up to thirty people. While we are scouring the entire coastal area for meal donations, chances are that we will have to supply meals for all our amazing, hungry actors! 

Promotion - 10%

    Promotional money will be going towards things such as festival entry fees and poster/sticker production.

Grip and Electric - 6%

Oasis of the Mind is shooting on location in a coastal marsh region. We will be renting generators and electrical equipment that will allow us to work on set as if we were in a studio. 

Contingency - 2% 

We have set a two percent contingency line in our budget to cover for any and every incident that could potentially occur that we could not have planned for.
story_txt: What would happen if the government ordered all of the nation’s incarcerated prisoners to retreat to an island to live amongst each other and fend for themselves? Citizens may support this change as these criminals are seen as problematic and forgettable. Oasis of the Mind tells the story of a curious guard’s journey rediscovering the humanity that was lost in these prisoners. Our film will tell this story of a theoretical future for our world. In Oasis of the Mind, a law is passed that casts citizens, known as “Deplorables,” out to a deserted Island in an attempt to maintain order within their society, known as “The Nation.” When a new guard, Danni, is stationed on the island, she soon notices abnormal behavior amongst the Deplorables. This inspires her to look deeper into the Deplorables and their way of living. She does this through developing a relationship with one female prisoner in particular, named Armina. By observing Armina’s tribe on the Island, Danni learns the truth behind The Nation's blinded morality. Through this newfound awareness, she becomes more empathetic and considerate towards the Deplorables. Danni begins to see the Deplorables as her equals.Through Oasis of the Mind, we want to shed light on the misconceptions of the prison system. Our team hopes to communicate to our audience that some incarcerated individuals are able to heal from the world’s mistakes. These individuals deserve to be treated as humans, not just as an embodiment of their past mistakes.This film also explores the instinctive sense of purpose found when humans are placed in a primitive state of living- exemplifying our connection to nature. Living in the wild presents many challenges and creates possibilities for people to help one another survive and in turn creating a community. Reprioritizing one’s mind to focus on surviving first and foremost can open many doors to healing as a result.  Oasis of the Mind is our senior capstone project that will cumulatively embody the talent, professionalism, and dedication of our entire cast and crew. It has been a productive four-year journey here at SCAD and we are bursting at the seams with excitement to bring Oasis of the Mind into production to share with you. In order to do so, we need your help! Fundraising will go directly towards each department of our film to fund things like props, costumes, location fees, transportation, and equipment. Our  project is very heavily depending on the support of our friends, family, and maybe some people we haven’t even met yet. We have some really neat incentives we will be distributing to our supporters as a token of our gratitude. You can check them out on the right side of this campaign page!Every contribution from our supporters will bring us closer to reaching our goal. A little bit goes a long way in student filmmaking. Even sharing our campaign with your family and friends will bring additional traffic to our page, so go ahead and copy our link below and post it to your accounts!There are several ways for you to help!FOLLOW along with our journey on Instagram https://www.instagram.com/_oasisofthemind_/  Join the oasis and CONTRIBUTE to our campaign https://www.indiegogo.com/projects/oasis-of-the... SHARE our campaign with your friends and family on social media https://www.indiegogo.com/projects/oasis-of-the...Thank you in advance for all of your help and for supporting our dream! We absolutely could not do this without you! The smoking hot graphic below depicts the percentages of our total funding that will be distributed to each department on our team. Breakdowns of specific departments’ needs can also be found below.Art Department and Construction - 40%The art department is a huge part of Oasis of the Mind! Our amazing production designer, Tierney Brennan, has done her very best to deliver the vision that Eryn has brought forwards. This part of the budget will be going towards costuming and set construction for the film. Set Operations - 22%Filming select scenes will require police and firemen supervision. Part of the set operations funding will go towards paying these members of our community who generously take the time to help us out!Food - 20%One of our filming days, we will be feeding up to thirty people. While we are scouring the entire coastal area for meal donations, chances are that we will have to supply meals for all our amazing, hungry actors! Promotion - 10%    Promotional money will be going towards things such as festival entry fees and poster/sticker production.Grip and Electric - 6%Oasis of the Mind is shooting on location in a coastal marsh region. We will be renting generators and electrical equipment that will allow us to work on set as if we were in a studio. Contingency - 2% We have set a two percent contingency line in our budget to cover for any and every incident that could potentially occur that we could not have planned for.

story:
The Film

Scarlett doesn't play by the rules. She wasn't raised like the rest of us, being forced to move from city to city, hotel to hotel. She's a dangerous girl, and crossing paths with her could destroy you. But what happens when a girl like her falls in love?

What We Need

Our goal is to raise at least $7,000. We're half way through filming and need to raise money for additional costs for cast and crew, food, locations, legal, post-production, film festival submission costs, press-kits for the festivals, etc.

Human-Trafficking

The story was based off of real life stories of people who have been forced into and suffered through the unseen reality of human trafficking. We'll be interviewing some of these girls. Their stories need to be heard. It's a terrible aspect of our society and needs to be stopped.

We Need Your Help

PrettyBabyBeautiful is a jumping off point for many of the cast and crew involved in this film. We hope it will be a platform for launching our careers forwards as actors and filmmakers.

So please check out our perks, and help us out by donating now!!!

Even if you can't donate, help share and spread the word about our project!

Thank you :)

story:
Why this script of mine, "Neutral land"?  

It's a story having a flight assistant as the female protagonist and a man committed to decide about his future as the male protagonist. I've always had my curiosity arisen by the profession of the flight assistant - travelling or escaping from something? Moreover revenge is a principle that always works in a movie. This way the female and male protagonists are linked in their roles. Everything seems romantic untill... I like the capability of a film to astonish the public and make them feel great emoctions. Emoctions are the nourishement of heart and mind.  

After shooting the video you already watched, my short was awarded also in Venezuela as "Best opera prima", in Alaska with "Northern lights emergin talent award" and in Hollywood with "Best first time filmaker". The U.S. Premiere will be at the Buffalo Niagara International Film Festival on the 28th ot September 8pm.

Who is me?

I was born in Cecina (LI) in 1991. I've always lived in the tuscan countryside, influenced by its beauty.
I like writing about what I see, just as cinema is: an eye that sees what is around highlighting any single detail.

I believe in cinema the way a child believes in fairy tales. I think everything is possible with a great idea, a good script and a team.
Cinema is emoction and this is my goal: to share emoctions, to make people touched by my work.

I graduated at Bologna University in Drama, Art and Music Studies in 2013. While I was at the University I published a poem collection and a tale about violence against women, written from the point of view of a woman.
My first short "The blind side" is still submitted to many film festivals all around the world, having success beyond expectations.
The same for my second screenplay "Neutral land".

Are you a producer and would like to help?

I will really appreciate that.

Are you a member of a flight company and would like it to be advertised in this short movie? We need uniforms

It will be a great advertising for your flight company

Do you know any goldsmith who would like to show an astounding diamond ring? Please let me know

After watching this film, everybody would like to buy the same diamond ring
