story:
(Olli Haaskivi, co-writer // Maria Dizzia, director // Joseph Medeiros, co-writer // Meghann Fahy, producer)

 

Karens Unanimous

is a film about one young woman's search for meaning, one cult's search for two hundred thousand dollars, the families we find, and how we carry the important events that shape us for the rest of our lives.

...it's also a rollicking, strange, hilarious adventure. 

 

Nuts + Bolts

We will be shooting in January for approximately three weeks.

Your generous donations will pay for many things, including but not limited to:

  • fair wages for the cast and crew
  • beautiful locations
  • state of the art equipment
  • good food
  • excellent wardrobe
  • top notch post production services
  • future film festival submissions
  • the rights to a Paula Abdul song

Every dollar counts and we are honored that you are considering donating and becoming part of our team. 

 

Our Team

MARIA DIZZIA (director / actor)

film: Christine, Martha Marcy May Marlene, Margin Call, Going in Style, The Happy Sad, True Story, While We're Young, Rachel Getting Married

television: Horace and Pete, Louie, Orange is the New Black, 13 Reasons Why, The Newsroom, Royal Pains, Red Oaks

broadway: Tony nomination for In The Next Room or The Vibrator Play

MEGHANN FAHY (producer / actor)

film: Miss Sloane, Lily + Mara, Those People, Burning Bodhi 

television: series lead of Freeform’s The Bold Type, Chicago Fire, Political Animals, Necessary Roughness, One Life to Live 

broadway: Next To Normal 

OLLI HAASKIVI (co-writer / actor)

film: Nancy, Dish, Freak Show, Get Happy, Going in Style, The Funeral Guest, Who We Are Now 

television: Mr. Robot, Unbreakable Kimmy Schmidt, Odd Mom Out, The Blacklist, Difficult People

JOSEPH MEDEIROS (co-writer / actor) 

film: Dish, Hairbrained, Vivace! 

broadway: nine shows including Matilda, West Side Story, and the recent Groundhog Day

 

Other Attached Actors

We feel so lucky to have some unbelievably unique, inventive, extraordinary actors committed to being a part of Karens Unanimous. Schedules change all the time but as of now, here are some of the folks who are planning to be on board...

Aaron Serotsky (The Marvelous Mrs. Maisel)

Sarah Stiles (Get Shorty)

Arian Moayed (Tony nominee for Bengal Tiger at the Baghdad Zoo)

Larisa Oleynik (Mad Men)

Taylor Trensch (upcoming Evan Hansen on Broadway in Dear Evan Hansen)

Jennifer Blood (final Miss Honey in Broadway's Matilda)

Rebecca Naomi Jones (The Big Sick)

.......and many more to be announced soon!!!

 

The Bottom Line

We are so thankful you are here considering our project. If you'd like to read the script or get in touch for any reason, don't hesitate to write KarensUnanimous@gmail.com. 

 

Love,

Your New Karen Friends

story:
We are Sam Sparxs Studio!

 

I am Samenta Agee, founder and elite cinephile. In 2016 I was lucky enough to be able to spend about 4 months in LA working on various projects at Warner Bros, Amazon Studios, AFI and more. When responsibility in Texas called me away from the thrilling-yet tough-work of show business, I was devastated.

 

I was moving away to a state that didn’t have the same abundance of opportunities  that California had. Then an idea was presented to me:

 

How many people in Texas want the opportunity to have that kind of but can't leave the state.

 

Why not start my own studio? How does one start?

 

This film is the first project under the studio name.

 

What makes this project important?

 

Imagine yourself as a man.

 

(Insert a Denzel Washington voice)

 

I am in a really tough spot right now and I need quick cash. What can I do?

 

Does your mind go to some handyman services, mowing a lawn or painting a wall?

 

Imagine yourself as a woman.

 

(Insert breathy Marilyn Monroe voice)

 

I am in a really tough spot right now and I need quick cash. What can I do?

 

Does your mind immediately travel to some seedy motel or a date in a parked car at some abandoned lot?

 

This is exactly the kind of situation our lead finds herself in.

What Makes It Different?

 

The opportunity to know the man behind the ad, frankly.

Why Should You Invest?

 

 Other than wearing the title of 'Patron of the Arts'? This venture requires funding to pay for the crew/ location/ SFX. Without funding, an idea is just that… an idea. It is challenging to get a big idea, especially in film, made without generous backers.

 

 

Other ways you can help?

 We don't want you to have to answer an ad to contribute to us (See what we did there). If money is a little tight, share! We know you know someone, who probably knows someone.

story:
Short Summary

This short film, written and directed by Lara Weiner, is one of the eight chosen projects in the junior fiction film class at Montana State University. It is about a girl who receives a chain mail message, but does not send it. Chaos ensues, ending in tragedy.

What We Need & What You Get

We need funding for food, props, and possible location use fees. None of the money received with go to the crew or cast; everyone is volunteering their time to help get this film made.

When you donate, you will receive certain perks for your contribution.

  • $5 - You will receive your name in the "Special Thanks To:" credits
  • $10 - You will receive the previous perk plus a copy of the final script
  • $20 - You will receive the previous perks plus a signed photo of the main character, Mallory
  • $50 - You will receive the previous perks plus a DVD copy of the final film
  • $100 - You will receive the previous perks plus an Executive Producer credit in the film

The Impact

By donating, you will help to create a film that is fun, relatable, and emotionally impactful.

Other Ways You Can Help

If you can't donate (which is totally fine), please share this with friends and family. Getting the word out to others who will be able to donate is just as helpful for the campaign.

story:
THE LOW-DOWN

WOLFROY follows our most recent project, SARATOGA LIGHTS (2017), as the second chapter in a trio of films that all loosely exist in an interrelated world. It explores grief, betrayal, and evil with a western tinge...like David Lynch's BLUE VELVET by way of Ana Lily Amirpour. We’ll be filming in June and July 2018 over eight days in Saratoga, Texas and Austin, Texas. We have all the necessities mapped out and all we need is your help.

We need to raise $5,500 to create this feature-length film from pre-production to post and beyond. We know we’re asking the best people to help us reach our goal. Donate if you’re passionate about movies, if you love Texas filmmakers, or if you just want to be involved in the filmmaking world in a meaningful way. In exchange, we’re offering perks like featured titles in our film, the complete soundtrack, behind-the-scenes exclusive content, and, of course, an advanced digital copy of the finished work.

Your contribution goes a long way in helping us to build this world and bring this movie to life. Further, your involvement helps independent filmmaking continue to thrive. Check out the information below to see what we’re trying to create, how you can help, and what you can get for your donations or visit us at dtdfilms.com for more about us and our work.

We are grateful for any contribution and we can’t wait to make something amazing with you.

THE FILM

WHAT IS WOLFROY?
WOLFROY is a feature-length film about what’s lurking beneath the surface. A married couple dealing with tragedy slowly begins to spiral out of control as grief and distrust build between them, all the while the small Texas town they live in begins to reveal a more sinister force that threatens their very lives.

Director Randall La Rue explains: “I was going through a personal crisis and everything I had come to rely on was gone in a matter of months…As I started to deconstruct the first 30 years of my life, I had to face some harsh truths about the mistakes I had made. Out of that process, the story of WOLFROY emerged. It's a complicated story of grief and the tragedy that results from selfish decisions, however small or insignificant they may be.”

WOLFROY is a highly visual story. While our previous work, SARATOGA LIGHTS, was stylized by the way things were said, WOLFROY is all about what’s in between the words. Our mission is to create something visually and emotionally striking that explores the human condition in tragic circumstances. We believe we have the cast, crew, locations, and story to do just that.

WHAT IS SARATOGA?

Saratoga, Texas (population 1,146) is the location of our film both on screen and off. It is as much of a character in WOLFROY as the people who inhabit it.

A town of boom and bust, Saratoga started as the community of New Sour Lake. Originally touted as the location of a medicinal spring similar to that of Saratoga Springs, NY, the town didn't find commercial success until 1901 when the first large-scale drilling began for oil. Rife with oil and timber, a railway connection gave Saratoga room to flourish.

The spaces we've found in and on the outskirts of this rural Texas town enhance a feeling of isolation. The Big Thicket National Preserve and Bragg Road (aka the "Ghost Road") lend an atmosphere of otherworldly beings, caution, and small-town whispers.

The Big Thicket National Preserve

Described as one of the most biodiverse areas in the world outside of the tropics. It was established in 1974 and it, along with Big Cypress National Preserve, was one of the first national preserves to be created in the United States.

Our characters spend time within these trees; dense forest and more than 97,000 acres of land encompass them as they try to escape their circumstances. Mounting uncertainty of what’s lurking in the shadows of the leaves add to the paranoia and intensity and forces action into small spaces where our characters come directly into contact with their fears.

Bragg Road, or “The Ghost Road”

Bragg Road or "The Ghost Road" in Saratoga, Texas has become the subject of folk tales from locals and travelers alike. The former railroad bed is now a gravel road that stretches straight down for 8 miles, covered by trees on both sides that create a canopy overhead.

Otherworldly lights appear at night on this lonely road in Hardin County and many call the area haunted. There are numerous stories to explain these mysterious lights. A local favorite is that of a railroad worker who lost his head to a passing train - they say that the lights are his lantern in the night, a gleaming beacon to those among the living, as he walks the road seeking revenge and hoping to find his missing head.

WHAT IS ACCOMPLISHED?
With WOLFROY, we’re settling back into the haunted western landscape we love so much for another cinematic brush with supernatural forces and cruel circumstance.

With every shoot we do, we evolve and learn more as a storytellers and filmmakers. This shoot will be no different. For WOLFROY we’ve come prepared. We've upgraded our gear and have been hard at work planning every move. We have locations, cast & crew, filming dates, and budget already set. Now all we need to do is start!

The beauty of our process is that our crew has worked together on prior films. We know each other well and together we’ve created beautiful content over 6 years. We've learned what works and what doesn't and hope to push our boundaries in this film.  With help from financial backers, we can make an amazing piece of film.

THE PEOPLE


KOLBE RICKS as BONNIE


SPENCER GREENWOOD as SANFORD


SAIGE HILTON as PATRICIA


MATTHEW DAVID RUDD as NATHAN

ABOUT DTD

DTD is a collection of independent filmmakers and storytellers. Formed in 2011, we’ve created 3 feature films, 4 shorts films, and a web series together. Our work is built upon fostering a community where passion for the story pushes us to create art. We all have a voice in the creative process and work hard to bring forth individuality in the film world.

WHO’S WHO FOR WOLFROY


RANDALL LA RUE - Director, Writer
Randall LaRue started out in the indie music scene as both a songwriter and music video director for 15 years. He made the jump to narrative filmmaking in 2012 and worked on the first season of the Emmy-nominated program, Hardly Sound, on Austin PBS. Since then, he has written and directed multiple short films and three feature films. He also co-founded the film collective Dual Tape Deck in Austin, TX.

SAIGE HILTON - Producer
Saige Hilton is an Austin actor and stage manager. She has a Bachelor of Arts degree from Saint Edwards University. After graduating, she had the incredible opportunity to work for The Acting Company in New York City. There she did short films at NYU Tisch School of the Arts. After returning to Austin, Saige has worked on stage with Present Company and The City Theatre appearing in Hamlet, Rosencrantz & Guildenstern Are Dead, A Midsummer Nights Dream, Much Ado About Nothing, and Loves Labours Lost. She is thrilled to be working on her second feature film with Dual Tape Deck and enjoying her role as an actor and producer.

JORDAN TAYLOR - Producer
Jordan has been involved in theatre and film projects for the past decade, moving between acting and technical roles. After graduating with a Film & Theatre degree, she spent time as a radio editor and producer while working on projects in the DFW area. WOLFROY will be her third collaborative effort with Dual Tape Deck. Currently, she is applying to China and Korea to attain her Master's degree in Film and continue telling stories and creating art.

THE CONTRIBUTORS: YOU!

Are you driven to create? Collaborate on WOLFROY with us!

As artists, we encourage and enable each other to express ourselves and tell our stories in whatever ways we can. We’re driven by an inexplicable need to create. While our vision, creativity, and community can take us far, we need your help to see it through.

The production includes only 8 days of filming altogether, but it is a full-length movie with a main shooting location that is over 1,000 miles away for some of our crew. We believe we have a story worth telling and would love your support to tell it. With the money raised from this campaign we can cover:

  • Production Costs (crew/cast, equipment rentals)
  • Travel expenses to and from Saratoga, TX
  • Post production work (ADR, sound mixing, color grading, musical score)
  • Festival entrance fees

The contributions we receive will not only help with our filmmaking needs in a material sense, but it will allow us to make the film we see in our imagination. Indie filmmaking is about making films the way we want to, without having to obey the man behind the curtain. Sometimes we need financial help to make the film we envision.

THE EXTRA (OTHER WAYS TO HELP)

Are you a blogger, film critic, or lover of the arts? Looking for content to post on your site? We’d love to share our filmmaking journey or partner with you. Let us know what your ideas are.

Are you a freelancer or a brand representative for your company? Would you like to be featured in our film, or help in raising funds for our campaign? We'd love to collaborate with you or feature your products if we can. Give us an email here.

Are you a brand, venue, or just a volunteer who would like to help in another way not mentioned above? Send us a message here.

It's exciting and scary as we try to birth this thing and bring it to you. Creating films is what we love to do best. Please sign up for our mailing list at http://www.dtdfilms.com/hifi/ to follow along with updates and all kinds of behind-the-scenes access or hang out with us out online at:

     

FILM ON,
Dual Tape Deck
www.wolfroyfilm.com
story_txt:
THE LOW-DOWNWOLFROY follows our most recent project, SARATOGA LIGHTS (2017), as the second chapter in a trio of films that all loosely exist in an interrelated world. It explores grief, betrayal, and evil with a western tinge...like David Lynch's BLUE VELVET by way of Ana Lily Amirpour. We’ll be filming in June and July 2018 over eight days in Saratoga, Texas and Austin, Texas. We have all the necessities mapped out and all we need is your help.We need to raise $5,500 to create this feature-length film from pre-production to post and beyond. We know we’re asking the best people to help us reach our goal. Donate if you’re passionate about movies, if you love Texas filmmakers, or if you just want to be involved in the filmmaking world in a meaningful way. In exchange, we’re offering perks like featured titles in our film, the complete soundtrack, behind-the-scenes exclusive content, and, of course, an advanced digital copy of the finished work.Your contribution goes a long way in helping us to build this world and bring this movie to life. Further, your involvement helps independent filmmaking continue to thrive. Check out the information below to see what we’re trying to create, how you can help, and what you can get for your donations or visit us at dtdfilms.com for more about us and our work.We are grateful for any contribution and we can’t wait to make something amazing with you.THE FILM
WHAT IS WOLFROY?WOLFROY is a feature-length film about what’s lurking beneath the surface. A married couple dealing with tragedy slowly begins to spiral out of control as grief and distrust build between them, all the while the small Texas town they live in begins to reveal a more sinister force that threatens their very lives.Director Randall La Rue explains: “I was going through a personal crisis and everything I had come to rely on was gone in a matter of months…As I started to deconstruct the first 30 years of my life, I had to face some harsh truths about the mistakes I had made. Out of that process, the story of WOLFROY emerged. It's a complicated story of grief and the tragedy that results from selfish decisions, however small or insignificant they may be.”WOLFROY is a highly visual story. While our previous work, SARATOGA LIGHTS, was stylized by the way things were said, WOLFROY is all about what’s in between the words. Our mission is to create something visually and emotionally striking that explores the human condition in tragic circumstances. We believe we have the cast, crew, locations, and story to do just that.WHAT IS SARATOGA?Saratoga, Texas (population 1,146) is the location of our film both on screen and off. It is as much of a character in WOLFROY as the people who inhabit it.A town of boom and bust, Saratoga started as the community of New Sour Lake. Originally touted as the location of a medicinal spring similar to that of Saratoga Springs, NY, the town didn't find commercial success until 1901 when the first large-scale drilling began for oil. Rife with oil and timber, a railway connection gave Saratoga room to flourish.The spaces we've found in and on the outskirts of this rural Texas town enhance a feeling of isolation. The Big Thicket National Preserve and Bragg Road (aka the "Ghost Road") lend an atmosphere of otherworldly beings, caution, and small-town whispers.The Big Thicket National PreserveDescribed as one of the most biodiverse areas in the world outside of the tropics. It was established in 1974 and it, along with Big Cypress National Preserve, was one of the first national preserves to be created in the United States.Our characters spend time within these trees; dense forest and more than 97,000 acres of land encompass them as they try to escape their circumstances. Mounting uncertainty of what’s lurking in the shadows of the leaves add to the paranoia and intensity and forces action into small spaces where our characters come directly into contact with their fears.Bragg Road, or “The Ghost Road”Bragg Road or "The Ghost Road" in Saratoga, Texas has become the subject of folk tales from locals and travelers alike. The former railroad bed is now a gravel road that stretches straight down for 8 miles, covered by trees on both sides that create a canopy overhead.Otherworldly lights appear at night on this lonely road in Hardin County and many call the area haunted. There are numerous stories to explain these mysterious lights. A local favorite is that of a railroad worker who lost his head to a passing train - they say that the lights are his lantern in the night, a gleaming beacon to those among the living, as he walks the road seeking revenge and hoping to find his missing head.WHAT IS ACCOMPLISHED?With WOLFROY, we’re settling back into the haunted western landscape we love so much for another cinematic brush with supernatural forces and cruel circumstance.With every shoot we do, we evolve and learn more as a storytellers and filmmakers. This shoot will be no different. For WOLFROY we’ve come prepared. We've upgraded our gear and have been hard at work planning every move. We have locations, cast & crew, filming dates, and budget already set. Now all we need to do is start!The beauty of our process is that our crew has worked together on prior films. We know each other well and together we’ve created beautiful content over 6 years. We've learned what works and what doesn't and hope to push our boundaries in this film.  With help from financial backers, we can make an amazing piece of film.THE PEOPLEKOLBE RICKS as BONNIESPENCER GREENWOOD as SANFORDSAIGE HILTON as PATRICIA MATTHEW DAVID RUDD as NATHANABOUT DTDDTD is a collection of independent filmmakers and storytellers. Formed in 2011, we’ve created 3 feature films, 4 shorts films, and a web series together. Our work is built upon fostering a community where passion for the story pushes us to create art. We all have a voice in the creative process and work hard to bring forth individuality in the film world.WHO’S WHO FOR WOLFROYRANDALL LA RUE - Director, WriterRandall LaRue started out in the indie music scene as both a songwriter and music video director for 15 years. He made the jump to narrative filmmaking in 2012 and worked on the first season of the Emmy-nominated program, Hardly Sound, on Austin PBS. Since then, he has written and directed multiple short films and three feature films. He also co-founded the film collective Dual Tape Deck in Austin, TX.SAIGE HILTON - ProducerSaige Hilton is an Austin actor and stage manager. She has a Bachelor of Arts degree from Saint Edwards University. After graduating, she had the incredible opportunity to work for The Acting Company in New York City. There she did short films at NYU Tisch School of the Arts. After returning to Austin, Saige has worked on stage with Present Company and The City Theatre appearing in Hamlet, Rosencrantz & Guildenstern Are Dead, A Midsummer Nights Dream, Much Ado About Nothing, and Loves Labours Lost. She is thrilled to be working on her second feature film with Dual Tape Deck and enjoying her role as an actor and producer.JORDAN TAYLOR - ProducerJordan has been involved in theatre and film projects for the past decade, moving between acting and technical roles. After graduating with a Film & Theatre degree, she spent time as a radio editor and producer while working on projects in the DFW area. WOLFROY will be her third collaborative effort with Dual Tape Deck. Currently, she is applying to China and Korea to attain her Master's degree in Film and continue telling stories and creating art.THE CONTRIBUTORS: YOU!Are you driven to create? Collaborate on WOLFROY with us!As artists, we encourage and enable each other to express ourselves and tell our stories in whatever ways we can. We’re driven by an inexplicable need to create. While our vision, creativity, and community can take us far, we need your help to see it through.The production includes only 8 days of filming altogether, but it is a full-length movie with a main shooting location that is over 1,000 miles away for some of our crew. We believe we have a story worth telling and would love your support to tell it. With the money raised from this campaign we can cover:
Production Costs (crew/cast, equipment rentals)
Travel expenses to and from Saratoga, TX
Post production work (ADR, sound mixing, color grading, musical score)
Festival entrance fees
The contributions we receive will not only help with our filmmaking needs in a material sense, but it will allow us to make the film we see in our imagination. Indie filmmaking is about making films the way we want to, without having to obey the man behind the curtain. Sometimes we need financial help to make the film we envision.THE EXTRA (OTHER WAYS TO HELP)Are you a blogger, film critic, or lover of the arts? Looking for content to post on your site? We’d love to share our filmmaking journey or partner with you. Let us know what your ideas are.Are you a freelancer or a brand representative for your company? Would you like to be featured in our film, or help in raising funds for our campaign? We'd love to collaborate with you or feature your products if we can. Give us an email here.Are you a brand, venue, or just a volunteer who would like to help in another way not mentioned above? Send us a message here.It's exciting and scary as we try to birth this thing and bring it to you. Creating films is what we love to do best. Please sign up for our mailing list at http://www.dtdfilms.com/hifi/ to follow along with updates and all kinds of behind-the-scenes access or hang out with us out online at:      FILM ON,Dual Tape Deckwww.wolfroyfilm.com

story:
Summary

  • My name is Josh Mangrum.  As teenage filmmaker, I have written, filmed and directed short films, commercials and promos for personal projects and clients in several states.  Now, with my dedicated crew and this talented cast, I want to turn this award-winning animation into a live action story that will help heal families.  

  • By donating money or social influence, you will help share a wonderful message on fatherhood, and recieve some great perks as thanks for your generous contribution!

What We Need & What You Get

  • We have equipment, script, and locations covered already.  We just need $1,500 to cover costumes, transportation, lodging and some crew expenses.  Yes, I make short films on an extremely tight budget, and it helps that most cast and crew are volunteers :).
  • Just a few of the Perks include: Screen credit with you listed as an Executive Producer; a Poster signed by the Cast and Crew; Behind the Scenes footage, and more!

The Impact

  • This film will encourage all parents and children to connect.
  • You will also have my eternal appreciation for supporting my aspirations as a filmmaker, as well as the careers of my actors and crew (who are also known as my fellow students, friends and family).  

Other Ways You Can Help

  • Besides money, we would appreciate a shout out on social media about the film as we near our release date. Use #FatherDaughterDance.
  • If you are a professional actor and work really cheap or can donate some time to this cause, we are still casting for the father.  If we exceed our goal, we can hire for this role.
  • Also consider checking out Prison Fellowship's angel tree project: https://www.prisonfellowship.org/about/angel-tree/

The Team

Alex - Daughter

Mark - Sheriff

Joshua - Director

Samuel - Assistant Director

story:
TRUE STORY, PLEASE CONTRIBUTE NOW.

We are funding:

1) A Good Zombie Movie

2) A Good Zombie Series to air on Roku and Amazon Prime

3) Seed Capital to Launch our Roku Channel; Mad Chaos TV

SYNOPSIS: It's a beautiful late New England fall day when two International College Students go missing on an afternoon jog. The general consensus by local law enforcement is they ran into dangerous wild life as Black Bears roam the surrounding forests. Meanwhile two yuppies venture off into a nearby rural community adjacent to where the joggers have gone missing. As they realize something is off center, they soonly discover that there has been an explosion at the nearby RUSSELTOWN NUCLEAR POWER PLANT. After encountering several disfigured people who seem to have an acquired taste for human limbs and brains. They have concluded that the Power Plant employees have been infected by the immediate blast through radiation and other townspeople as well. Therefore they must fight off thousands of flesh eating zombies and avoid radioactive materials that are now airborne in order to live another day.  

Starring: Kendra Lust as Sheriff Patricia Grealey in first ever Horror/Thriller/Sci-Fi Genre movie. We also have an experienced ensemble cast from the New York City and Boston film markets. 

GENRE: Horror, Thriller, Sci-Fi

LOGLINE: Every town has its secrets, the small New England Town of Russeltown, VT has one too many. 

COMPS: Night of the Living Dead, Outbreak, Dawn of the Dead, Shawn of the Dead, World War Z.

Brought to you from the Director of Indie Cult Classic "BLOOD RESERVOIR" comes a new tale that should take the Horror Genre and beyond by Storm. Starring KENDRA LUST in her first Horror Film role playing one of the stories Protagonists "Sheriff Patricia Grealey." We are asking fans to help make this the best film possible. Funding for the production is already secured, however we need your help to adding more billable names to the cast, but most importantly we need WICKED COOL SPECIAL EFFECTS. We're talking massive fires and explosions, Zombies, Zombie Bears and other Creatures harrowing through the night while gorgeous babes like KENDRA kill them! YES we seriously have a ZOMBIE BEAR! We already had a Stop Motion Puppet made and his movement scenes have been recorded. We went old school Ray Harryhausen Practical Effects style on this one. 

 

Our Ensemble Cast are no strangers to the silver screen, and Television their credits include; Jurassic Park, The Judge, Gotham, The Blacklist and many more! 

Featuring: Emma Mackenzie, Andi Balser, Nat Sylva and Ian Lyons. 

Your funding will go to:

*Booking 1-2 more Billable names, preferably Legends within the Horror Genre. 

* SPECIAL EFFECTS, more BLOOD, more GORE, more FLESH EATING ZOMBIES! No CGI we only use PRACTICAL EFFECTS.

*Over 100 film making jobs consisting of cast and crew.

*Stop Motion Animation Puppet(s)

*Marketing on Social Media, Twitter, Instagram, Facebook, Snap Chat and online magazines such as Fangoria, Rue Morgue, Bloody Disgusting, Variety, The Hollywood Reporter.

OFFICIAL MOVIE POSTER

SWOT ANALYSIS

Strengths: We have an experienced cast and crew along with a well known Starlett in Kendra Lust who currently has millions of fans worldwide. Not to mention we have an amazing script written by a brilliant screen writer who placed high in the Nicholl Fellowship.  

Weaknesses: Some may say that the Zombie genre is dying down, however we disagree and look at that opinion as a strength. The reasoning is some Zombie shows have lost their edge and creativity, it time to start fresh with a new storyline. 

Opportunities: This can be the next great zombie Franchise as Distribution is secured through Amazon Direct Video, self released DVD's, and other Online Streaming Opportunities such as ROKU Streaming Channels and APPLE TV. 

Threats: A highly saturated zombie genre market, however competition raises the bar on quality. Which is why we are having this campaign. We just do not want to make another zombie movie. We want to make a legendary cult classic!!!

Other Ways You Can Help

If you can not make a financial contribution to this campaign, please help spread the word by sharing this link. Thank you. 

Concept Art, Story Boards 

 

                              

                              

 

                 

  

 

From the Director of ALEISTER

WATCH ALEISTER NOW BY CLICKING ON LINK BELOW:

https://www.amazon.com/Aleister-Mark-Anthony-De...

and BLOOD RESERVOIR

WATCH BLOOD RESERVOIR BY CLICKING ON LINK BELOW

https://www.amazon.com/Blood-Reservoir-FelissaRose/dp/B00U83H39K

and a Co-Executive Producer of BLUE LINE

Comes a New Zombie Franchise: DEAD TOWN!!!

Other Ways You Can Help

Concept Art, Story Boards 
 
                              
                              
 
                 
  

 

From the Director of ALEISTER
WATCH ALEISTER NOW BY CLICKING ON LINK BELOW:
https://www.amazon.com/Aleister-Mark-Anthony-De...

and BLOOD RESERVOIR

story:
ENGRAM

www.engram-film.com

On 11.VI.2247 the transit of Venus took place in front of the sun's disk. This rare astronomical phenomenon was thought to herald the end of the current world. Believing in the impending catastrophe, people fell into madness and excess, taking their own lives and fighting a war that claimed billions of victims, leaving desolation in its wake. However, the apocalyptic prophecy did not come true, and man survived.

 

SYNOPSIS

The former Polish-Russian border in a decaying Europe. Geographic boundaries have been obliterated, and traces of war - like a stain - are reflected in the fragile identities of the surviving humans. The illusory beauty of the landscape opens its raw image - a picture whose frame deteriorates, rots, breaks into pieces. This fragmentation is reflected in minimalistic pictures of intimate relationships, showing a human being who - like an animal - on a leash, in a muzzle, in a cage of his own fear - can no longer come close to another.  It is too late for any deed, and the dignity lost cannot be regained. 

 

DIRECTOR'S NOTE

In these times, we are immersed in the dark reality of inarticulate fear that leaves behind moral havoc, alienation and insensitivity to the events of the present. ENGRAM is the reverse of this reality - it is its reflection - an attempt to look at the sources and effects of this fear.

The film in its totality refers to the issues of guilt, forgiveness and responsibility for moral choices seen through the prism of a wound that is so old, so deep and so painful that it has become impossible to heal.

Based on the inner dynamics of borderline situations, ENGRAM will oscillate in its form between onirism and brutality, beauty and ugliness, dream and naturalistic cruelty.

Between splintered glances, we see what one is not allowed to look at. Between broken words, we speak of what has been consumed by silence. Tragedy is inevitable, so let the ode to INJUSTICE be chanted! Because there is no punishment for sin or reward for virtue.  Therefore, M. asks: Does it matter who is guilty if there is no one who can judge?

 

REALISATION

Based on the belief that the most important foundation of this work is the talent and craft of its participants, the actors, filmmakers and artists who will realise this project came together through a noncoincidental encounter. 

The film will be photographed in saturated colors on 16mm film and Video by Nikodem Marek. Electronic musical motifs will be composed by legendary Japanese sound artist Fumiyuki Nagura (Mo*Te).

To fabricate the space of the represented world of ENGRAM, we will combine footage from the Baltic Coast with coherent recordings made in Iceland.

The film will be produced under modest production conditions, but to create ENGRAM faithfully, we need your help, which is why we have decided to organize this fundraiser.

In order to shoot the film, the cast and crew of 25 people will need to be continuously present on locations far from their everyday lives for several weeks. It will be necessary to provide accommodation, meals and means of travel during this time.

In addition to the purely logistical costs of these shoots, we require funds from this fundraiser for the creation of set design, costumes, props, special effects and a symbolic reimbursement to the wonderful, dedicated actors and musicians participating in this project.

To repay your invaluable contribution to the production of ENGRAM, we would like to send all supporters various gifts in the form of original materials, artworks and unique artefacts from the production process.

 

ABOUT THE AUTHOR

Basia Napora was born in 1990, in Jelenia Góra, Poland. She studied art history at the University of Wrocław, visual communication at Peter Behrens School of Arts in Düsseldorf, and film directing and screenwriting at the Academy of Media Arts Cologne. Her work is rooted in photography and traditional techniques. Since 2010, she has been working with video and short narrative formats. Permeating theatrical-literary contexts find synthesis in her recent film work. In 2018, together with Oskar Brummel, she made the short film Love Forgives Everything, which premiered in May 2019 at Kino Pod Baranami in Krakow, Poland. ENGRAM is her first feature film, whose inception dates back to 2017.

In order to shoot the film, the cast and crew of 25 people will need to be continuously present on locations far from their everyday lives for several weeks. It will be necessary to provide accommodation, meals and means of travel during this time.
In addition to the purely logistical costs of these shoots, we require funds from this fundraiser for the creation of set design, costumes, props, special effects and a symbolic reimbursement to the wonderful, dedicated actors and musicians participating in this project.
To repay your invaluable contribution to the production of ENGRAM, we would like to send all supporters various gifts in the form of original materials, artworks and unique artefacts from the production process.
 

ABOUT THE AUTHOR
Basia Napora was born in 1990, in Jelenia Góra, Poland. She studied art history at the University of Wrocław, visual communication at Peter Behrens School of Arts in Düsseldorf, and film directing and screenwriting at the Academy of Media Arts Cologne. Her work is rooted in photography and traditional techniques. Since 2010, she has been working with video and short narrative formats. Permeating theatrical-literary contexts find synthesis in her recent film work. In 2018, together with Oskar Brummel, she made the short film Love Forgives Everything, which premiered in May 2019 at Kino Pod Baranami in Krakow, Poland. ENGRAM is her first feature film, whose inception dates back to 2017.

story:
Story:

Vincent (30s) stares deep into the cosmos of the room, he hasn’t slept in days yet his focus is unbroken. Velma (40s) enters the room like a bull in a china shop, she brushes her face and then takes a seat opposite Vincent. They begin playing tennis with their words, dancing around the subject of Charlotte: a two-year-old that has gone missing. The deeper they delve, the more we learn of these two characters. Finally it becomes clear to us that Vincent is the police detective and Velma is being investigated. The extremities of Velma’s mental condition have led her to abduct Charlotte. In an attempt to crack the case, Vincent becomes Velma’s therapist. By forcing her to face what she is running from, Velma reveals the information that is needed to rescue Charlotte. When Charlotte is found, the healing process begins for Velma.

Creative vision:

My team and I believe that this is an important story, both as a character study and as a slow burning psychological drama. Now is a time that mental health is being spoken about more than ever due to the current pandemic. We’d like to offer our take on the extremities of how mental health can influence one’s actions based from a psychological point of view. Our vision is to make an Artistic film that will amaze its audiences both at festivals and online.

Director's Statement:

One of my beliefs is that everything comes from somewhere:  the psychology of a person is usually created from their individual experiences in life and the different environments into which they were born. My aim, when developing this script with writer Tom Wilton, was to create a deep seeded psychological drama from which the audience has to work to untangle the psychology of each character.

The story is a poem about mental health and how most of us end up repeating what has happened to us in the past unless we are able to break the chains of associated behavior from the past. The solution is found in acceptance, love and courage.

Each scene is like a layer of the psyche: the deeper we go into it, the closer we get to finding our true selves through the detachment of our egos.

This is a very exciting script for me to bring to life as a director. My ultimate aim when I make any film is to teach the audiences something new about themselves and the world in which we inhabit.

I aim to take the audience on a journey through the unconscious dimensions of this story by using visual metaphors and unique sounds and by assisting the actors to deliver great performances.

I am confident that I will achieve my vision.

Cast

Dudley O'shaugnessy to play Vincent (Confirmed)

Dudley is an English ABA welterweight boxing champion, actor and model. Dudley appeared in Rihanna’s sensational music video We Found Love. Since then, he has starred in films such as White Color Black, The Spoiler and the hit British TV show Topboy. Dudley’s strength, sensibility and quirkiness will work wonderfully in the role of Vincent.

Actress to play Velma TBC

Characters

Velma: (40s) lives a routine life alone. She works Monday-Saturday at her local supermarket and spends her Sundays with her parents who are elderly. She’s an only child and has no children of her own. When Velma was 2 years old, she was abducted. After 7 months, her uncle Sam returned her to her home. Sam claimed the £50,000 reward money from an anonymous beneficiary; he also claimed to have found Velma wandering the streets alone. To this day, Velma has never spoken about the event. When Sam died recently, it triggered something in her that sent her down a road of mania. She stopped showing up for work and stopped visiting her parents. And a week or so after the death of Sam, she abducted a two year old girl named Charlotte. Velma then held Charlotte in the same shipping container in which she had been kept. In this moment when our story finds her, Velma’s mental state and subsequent actions are unpredictable. She’s erratic, cold, harsh, and, at the same time, very sensitive and vulnerable.

Vincent: (30s) is a police detective inspector. He achieved the title of this role at a young age by being very hard working and talented. Vincent prides himself on his unique ability to see things in a way that other detectives cannot. His unusual and sometimes slightly bizarre tactics result in him being an outsider. Vincent grew up in a busy household with his mother and three brothers; he is the second youngest. His father went back to Africa when Vincent was just a boy and has never returned. Vincent spent most of his childhood with his grandfather, soaking up old wisdom. When Vincent’s grandfather died, he began looking at things differently. Since then, he has solved every case that has been assigned to him. Vincent is bold, strong and introverted. He carries a very calm and controlled demeanor but can explode at any moment. There is no limit to where he will go to solve a case.

Budget

  • Cast: £1500 - Paying our actors for their time and hard work is very important for us to secure the top talent and create a professional working environment.
  • Extras: £350 - We will require extras to help us achieve a strong sense of realism throughout the story. Specific scenes such as the crime scene where Charlotte is found will require a number of uniformed police officers.
  • Crew: £6250 - Our crew will all be preparred to work for the same day-rate regardless of their position.
  • Locations: £1850 - Locations set the tone and feel of the piece, it's important that we secure interesting and realistic locations to tell this story.
  • Production: £5905 - Our production costs will include ; Camera, Film equipment, Film stock and developing, Art department, Wardrobe, Meals for cast and crew, travel & accomodation.
  • Post production: £3900 Post production costs will include; Editing, Music/score, Colourist, Sound-Engineer, DCP, EPK & Festival submissions.
  • Insurance: £444.48 - Given these times of the current pandemic it's important we have a good insurance that will cover us not only for equipment and location damages but also that will insure us incase anyone in our team were to catch the virus.
  • Contingency: £800 - To cover any additional costs that we may encounter along the way.

Crew

Director/Writer: Josh Kidd

Josh is a Writer, Director, Editor and Producer. Having previously been an actor he also has a string of acting credit's to his name. He has directed Short films Wirelines and On your own time before making the huge step to direct "Nectar" his first feature film. Nectar is currently on a festival run and recently played at American Black Film Festival. Josh's choice to stop acting and focus entirely on directing was motivated by his passion to create a new wave in film. He believes that by having all of his attention behind camera he will be able to master his language in cinema.

Writer: Tom Wilton

Tom Wilton is a London-born writer, producer, and director based in New York City.

A self-taught filmmaker, Wilton is known for micro-budget feature films Let It Go (2014) and the award-winning Vinyl (2010). His recent short documentary Being C-Bunny (2019) has also picked up awards at Chain NYC Film Festival and Boynton Beach Short Film Festival. It was also an Official Selection at Cinequest Film and VR Festival 2020.

As a writer and producer, Wilton has collaborated with several other filmmakers on numerous other projects including Jeffrey P. Nesker for Elsewhere, NY, Heidi Miami Marshall for Muscle, and Kerri Lynn Miller and Maria McIndoo for Etymology.

    

Producer: Freddie Connor

Freddie Connor graduated from the prestigious Royal Central School of Speech &
Drama, London. He won the renowned “Award of Merit” as a producer for two years
in a row at the Accolade Global Film Competition (2016 & 2017). Freddie wrote and
produced the critically acclaimed drama “Heather’s Painting,” which has won 30
major awards including “Best Picture” at the Hollywood International Moving
Pictures Film Festival, 2017. He was one of the main producers of the feature film
“Baseline,” which sold to over 15 countries and was released by Studio Canal Plus in
the UK. The London Insider selected “Baseline” as one of the top 5 films of the year,
alongside “Inception.”

DOP: Andres Arochi

Andres is an audio-visual, self-taught and multidisciplinary artist who lives and works in Mexico City. His great interest in adventure and nature has led him to travel the world taking photographs and creating cinema. Through his insistent focus on geometry, textures and colours, his resulting images are always very bold and striking. Andres has worked on music videos for artists such as Major Lazer, FKJ, RYX and Farao. He has worked on short films:  Dissonance, Inferno, Shame and Bea. His activities with a camera revolve around the game with light and the search for the "inherent" rhythm of a scene. That search, along with his focus on the manipulation of light and composition, has produced his own original body of work of construct narrative. Arochi’s Artistic eye, technical knowledge and creative vision will contribute in creating an incredible visual language for the piece.

Composer: Dan “Chimy” Chmielinski

Dan is a New York Times critically acclaimed, award winning bassist, composer, producer and bandleader who consistently creates original projects under his own brand, Chimy Music. Dan has travelled the world, performing, collaborating and recording with world class musicians such as Wynton Marsalis, Joey Alexander and the Jazz at Lincoln Center Orchestra, to name a few. Dan has composed original scores for films such as; Smoke in the Air, I-RIS, Here Lies Truth and has most recently collaborated with director Josh Kidd on Nectar. Dan’s musical talents and understanding of emotions through music will help to form a great ocean of sound for this project.

Art Director: Camilla Herberstein

Camilla is an Award Winning Creative Director with more than 20 years global experience in the advertising industry. Camilla has lived and worked in France, Austria, Belgium and South Africa. She now resides in the U.K. Her work includes commercials for brands that range from Ford to Guinness. She prides herself on her acute attention to detail. Camilla has the talent and unique ability to bring all the multiple elements of film to life in each frame. This talent will be most welcome for developing the human dimensions of our story to deliver a truly extraordinary piece of art.

Short film - 15-20 minutes

Locations – In an around London

Camera – ARRI Sr3 Super 16mm film camera

Visual look - Black & White and Colour

Shoot dates - March 2021

Aim - To play at a top tier film festival, then be available online for audiences across the world.

story:
Daylight Savings

For as long as we’ve been telling scary stories we have always known that the light is what saves us; that no matter what happens if we just turn on the lamp will be safe from whatever lies in the dark. But what happens when you turn on the lights and the monster is still there? Logan is a simple college boy who has been thrust into an apocalyptic world overrun by monsters with no way to contact his family or friends. A curfew has been sent over the town that he lives in, as the monsters are only visible in direct light. Although Logan plays it safe, one night the lights in his home go out and the monsters use this as an opportunity to attack. Using only a hand flashlight, Logan must escape his predators that lie in the darkness. Luckily for Logan, these creatures don’t have very good eyesight in the dark much like humans so he can escape... As long as he’s quick, quiet, and stays in the light.

What We Need

As I said, anything and everything you donate will go straight to the film. We are preparing preproduction for the next several months and so the IndieGoGo is being opened now in order to get us on the track we need. The funds go in several different places, but mostly are aimed towards the prop and costume team on the film who are making our lovely monster. The funds also are geared towards providing food for the cast and crew, and even for helping us submit this film to festivals in the future.

What You Can Do

Donating even a dollar gets us on the right path. Even if you can't donate, just spreading around this campaign does something for us! We also accept food if you want to send cookies our way.

story:
From Writer/Director/Editor/Composer Mike Trebilcock:
 
 
I've been a musician for many years and have made music for television and films since the 80s. I spent some time in front of the camera doing interviews and shooting music videos for my band The Killjoys as we toured the country throughout the 90s. I had a hand in the making of most of these music videos, and that might be where I got the bug for making my own films; even though I'd been a film-lover since the brilliant stop-motion artist Ray Harryhausen blew all of our kid minds in the 60s and 70s. I really branched off into filmmaking myself almost ten years ago. I made films as part of a summer camp program in Dundas Ontario. One of those films, Werewolf Camp, has almost 75.000 views on YouTube and the number is steadily climbing. My short, Chewed, was an homage to many of the films I love, mainly Creepshow and Tales From The Crypt, where the bad guys satisfyingly get their comeuppance in the end. In October 2018, I finally wrote and directed a music video of my own for the band Among Monsters for their song Near Dark.
 
I have a passion for horror, humour, fantasy, the magic of special effects (especially practical), and overall effective story-telling. I love EC Comics, Spielberg's Amazing Stories series, The Twilight Zone, Tales From The Darkside and everything George A. Romero ever set his hand to. I guess that's where Spidermama comes in.
 
Spidermama
 
The idea for Spidermama came about about 4 years ago. My girlfriend's mom was nearing the end of her life a was residing in a nursing home. As much as they tried to keep her comfortable, the inconvenience and feeling of displacement was a lot for her to bear. I was always dreaming up ways for her to escape (I've also been a professional daydreamer since childhood), and Spidermama was born.
 
My 2019 Director's Reel
     

 

Making Spidermama

I learned a lot making my other crowdfunded film Chewed, and know that no matter how many corners you cut, how many friends and relatives generously help you out, volunteering time and expertise, and how much I can do on my own (I'm wearing too many hats to mention!) there are always things that need to be paid for. An experienced cast and crew, equipment rentals, production design, costumes, makeup, catering (a wise filmmaker once told me, "If you can't pay everyone, they at least need to be fed well!"), transportation, Air Bnbs, etc etc. and at the post-production stage, artwork, film festival submissions, marketing, etc... Things that you can't really cheap out on too much and still come out with a film that people want to watch and will be entertained by (and entertainment is always the goal for me). I would like people who work on my films to be happy and feel valued for their work. I've created a budget for Spidermama that comes in at just under the stated goal, but every bit will go to improve quality and viability of the movie. Even though the Chewed campaign didn't reach its goal, I came out of it slightly less broke than I would have without the generous contributions to that campaign.
 
Where does the money go?
The money raised here for the campaign will go toward actors, crew, rentals and construction of a few props, lights, sound and makeup! It all adds up, but contributes greatly to the quality of the finished product! 
 
 
Our Cast!
 
One of the most exciting aspects of Spidermama is the cast!
 
Lynne Griffin as Spidermama
 
As a horror fan, I'm incredibly excited to see Lynne play this part. She was in the Bob Clark classic, Black Christmas, as well as the weird and amazing Curtains, A lead role in The Adventures of Bob and Doug Mackenzie: Strange Brew, and a 2018 version of Fahrenheit 451.
From IMDB - "The talented Lynne Griffin started out on Canadian television in the early 1970s, then moved on to acting on stage. She is known for her work in Shakespearean plays and has frequently appeared at the Stratford Festival in Stratford, Ontario. She gave a notable performance in the television movie I'll Take Manhattan (1987), one of her rare acting performances in the US, most of her work being done in her home country of Canada. - IMDb Mini Biography By: aherron@lonestar.utsa.edu"
 
Peter Higginson - Mr. Grimes
 

 

I'm very excited to work with Peter as well. I loved his reel, and could sense his acting range, kindness, and professionalism. A perfect fit for Mr. Grimes!

From Mandy.com - "Theatre actor since 1956 with roles from Romeo to Lear in Shakespeare and Dysart (Equus) to George Reilly (Enter a Free Man) in contemporary theatre. Acted in film since 2004, enjoying his involvement in 10 to 20 TV, commercial or independent films a year."

 

Plan of ACTION!

We will be shooting May 4th and 5th of 2019. One day on set (hallway, room, lunchroom) and one day of SFX at QED Media in Hamilton. The film will be edited and scored over the next 3-4 months, and will then be sent to major festivals around the world!

It all adds up, but contributes greatly to the quality of the finished product!   Our Cast! One of the most exciting aspects of Spidermama is the cast! Lynne Griffin as Spidermama As a horror fan, I'm incredibly excited to see Lynne play this part. She was in the Bob Clark classic, Black Christmas, as well as the weird and amazing Curtains, A lead role in The Adventures of Bob and Doug Mackenzie: Strange Brew, and a 2018 version of Fahrenheit 451.From IMDB - "The talented Lynne Griffin started out on Canadian television in the early 1970s, then moved on to acting on stage. She is known for her work in Shakespearean plays and has frequently appeared at the Stratford Festival in Stratford, Ontario. She gave a notable performance in the television movie I'll Take Manhattan (1987), one of her rare acting performances in the US, most of her work being done in her home country of Canada. - IMDb Mini Biography By: aherron@lonestar.utsa.edu" Peter Higginson - Mr. Grimes  I'm very excited to work with Peter as well. I loved his reel, and could sense his acting range, kindness, and professionalism. A perfect fit for Mr. Grimes!From Mandy.com - "Theatre actor since 1956 with roles from Romeo to Lear in Shakespeare and Dysart (Equus) to George Reilly (Enter a Free Man) in contemporary theatre. Acted in film since 2004, enjoying his involvement in 10 to 20 TV, commercial or independent films a year." Plan of ACTION! We will be shooting May 4th and 5th of 2019. One day on set (hallway, room, lunchroom) and one day of SFX at QED Media in Hamilton. The film will be edited and scored over the next 3-4 months, and will then be sent to major festivals around the world!

story:
Dr. Karen Lentz doesn't know if she can ever be the same. A successful clinician and author, she struggles to make it through her morning routine, let alone the task of writing her upcoming book, a deadline that now seems meaningless. 

On the surface, one might say it's because the love of her life passed six months ago to the day. It also happens to be her 65th birthday. As she contends with the option of ending it all, her relationship to Tuolumne bubbles to the surface, and the depth of her connection to this storied wilderness is able to pull her back from the brink. 

This poignant, slice-of-life narrative shows how though loss can be terrifying, so is staring down the third act of life without the purpose you held onto for so long. Told through the eyes of a woman whose independence hangs in the balance, yet finds the power to stand on her own two feet once more. 

Kristen Joy Bjorge - Writer/Co-Director

Kristen Joy is an LA based writer/director & script consultant who focuses on character driven narratives, particularly those surrounding the female experience.

Kristen consults at top agency and management/production companies, having read over 400 scripts (and counting) in the past two years for actors Chadwick Boseman and Tessa Thompson. Her hour-long pilot, Kingdom of Children, was a finalist for the prestigious Blacklist/Women in Film episodic lab, and has advanced in every major TV screenwriting competition/fellowship including Sundance, BlueCat, and Austin Film Festival. This past March, Kristen was a visiting lecturer at the University of Illinois at Urbana-Champaign, teaching undergraduate senior BFA students in their nationally renowned theatre department. 

When she isn’t buried in a script, Kristen enjoys crossfit, swimming, and seeing as many movies as possible.

Alejandro Echevarria - Co-Director

Alejandro Echevarria is an independent filmmaker and freelance cameraman from Los Angeles. His short film, “Illusory Promises,” which stars Kristen Joy Bjorge, has received awards from the Los Angeles Reel Film Festival for Best Cinematography (DP: Erick Aguilar) and Best Short Narrative Film, in addition to screening as an Official Selection at NewFilmmakers Los Angeles, and the Independent Filmmakers Showcase (IFS).

He has worked in camera department in a broad range of capacities, including for television, broadcast news, feature-length concerts, commercials, music videos, Netflix original content and short films.

In his spare time, he enjoys playing ragtime piano.

Allen Chodakowski - Cinematographer

Allen Chodakowski is a cinematographer and camera operator who specializes in narrative motion pictures.

He moved out of Chicago six years ago after graduating from Columbia College’s film program, where he had the opportunity to shoot on 16mm and 35mm film. Upon graduating, he moved to LA and began working as a camera assistant. Since then he has shot short films, commercials and music videos. His short film “A Good Brother,” won Best Picture and Best Noir at the New York Film Awards and Best Film Noir at the Los Angeles Film Awards.

When stepping off set he spends his time cooking, watching movies and playing drums.

We anticipate around seventy percent of any funds received would go directly to production needs, including hiring a producer, permits, paying our crew and our actress, transportation, lodging and food for crew and talent, insurance, as well as any union fees. 

Our $50k goal also encompasses all post-production costs, including editing, sound design, hiring a composer, marketing, and festival fees. A thorough creative process throughout post is vital to making this film land. While we don’t want to rush ourselves, reaching our goal will help ensure we get through post efficiently without having to wait too long on any given process.

Below is a photo of our budget top sheet. Our full line item budget is also linked below. 

We are aiming to film Fall 2019, with post-production completed in time for Summer 2020 festival submissions. 

Link to Budget: http://bit.ly/2AvEJX7

Our intent is simple: use this story to touch on transparent, yet powerful messages. Loss, grief, and change are realities every human experiences, and the conduit through which we see this - Karen - is the reason we agree this story needs to be told now. The perspective of women over age sixty remains a story essentially untold in narrative film, and ageism (particularly when it comes to leading roles), continues to a be a hurdle of representation we’ve yet to overcome.

In 2017, the University of Southern California's Annenberg School for Communication published "Over Sixty, Underestimated" looking at age and representation in Best Picture Oscar nominees. Out of 1,256 speaking roles, only 148 were characters sixty years of age or over, with men accounting for 3.5 of those roles to every 1 female role. An earlier study also found that women over 40 only make up 21.4% of female roles, compared to 78.6% for men. 

Obviously, these numbers are not great.

It is so important to have older women be seen. Their wisdom, complexities, flaws, and beauty are unlike anything else on this planet. To grow old is at once a privilege and a certainty, and when we fail to fully represent this in the media, we erase a season of life that is so intricate and so important.  

Filming in a place of immense natural beauty, such as Tuolumne Meadows in Yosemite National Park, provides an illustrative background for us to bring this story to life. 

Nevertheless, it does come with its challenges, including the element of unknown (weather, etc), as well as paying for necessary permits that will allow us to film on this invaluable terrain. 

We are committed to the utmost integrity in telling this story, which includes respecting the land where filming will occur, working in cooperation with all Rangers and National Park staff as they ensure the well-being of both the park and the safety of our production. We have constructed our story in such a way as to not film in any conservation areas, ensuring we leave a small footprint and secure our permits, yet still remain true to the relationship between Karen and Tuolumne. 

We are ready and prepared for the journey of filming in Yosemite, knowing the story's relevance and the film's visual excellence will stand out in no small part due to the magnificence of the setting. 

I am so lucky to have had the opportunity to come to West Virginia and meet with many of you. The response to this project has been so inspiring, and it would be an absolute privilege to proudly express that this film's creation was made possible by a diverse group of individuals, far from the lights of Hollywood, who believed in the power of this film before anyone else would. 

If a donation isn't possible, sharing this film and this message with the people you know would mean the world to us. As many people as we can reach within the Mountain State and beyond, would go so far in my hope that creative partnerships in film can traverse state lines, bringing untold stories of people from all walks of life to the forefront. 

If you have any questions, feel free to reach out anytime at tuolumne.film@gmail.com.

Warmly, 

Kristen Joy

story:
Filmmakers Statement 

My name is Clare McCann and I was raised believing in magic, and would love to share that magic with you. Journey with me into the forest and be a part of creating wonder.

Five years ago, I left a corporate creative director role at The Star Casino. During my tenure, I produced and designed countless shows and creative productions, working with international celebrities and companies. I was driven however to move on and create something more meaningful and enthralling.

After humbly returning to university at the age of 25 to further my studies, I began working towards creating my own medieval productions. It has been a 5-year journey, working tirelessly on screenplays and self-funded film productions. 

After completing my directorial debut award-winning feature film Benefited this year, I am finally ready for the next step; creating a medieval short film. ‘Into the Forest’ will be used to help pitch my teams’ capabilities in this genre, towards the goal of having one of my larger pre-written medieval features or TV series fully funded and released on a larger scale. Securing paid work for my team and I, after all the years of volunteering and preparation, will be more than a dream come true…it will open the doors to the next stage of our professional and creative lives. And we would love your help in bringing our vision to life.

 

Our Head Production and Creative Team:

Kasumi Unagami - Production Assistant 

Yazmin Bradley - Production Assistant 

Magdalen Lovegrove - Associate Producer

Rhiannon D Margariti - Costume Designer

Laura Kierse - Art Director Assistant

 

What We Need & What You Get

I am asking you, dear reader, to help us reach our fundraising goal of $2,500.00. Achieving this along with our wonderful volunteer team will enable us to deliver an outstanding, quality-laden short film by mixing together all the best ingredients - from state-of-the-art camera, lighting and sound hire, glorious and authentic costumes, special effects equipment to scrumdidiliumptions catering for all our amazing volunteers. 

If you can help by donating to our production, you’ll have the enjoyment of being one of the first to see the finished film, and the satisfaction and pride in being publicly credited as an investor in the film. 

 

The Impact

An important aspect of our film production we are proud to note is a balanced number of male and female crew members. Cherry Productions is a passionate supporter of women in film, avidly working to create a safer and more welcoming film-making industry for women. 

We have originated multiple productions focused on women and women’s issues. Our latest film, the multi award-winning ‘Benefited’, has been selected to screen its international Premiere at the Women’s International Film & Arts Festival in New York. ‘Benefited’ brings needed attention to the ramifications of domestic violence, and the lack of safe housing support available for women and children trying to escape dangerous circumstances.

You can see more about Benefited here: www.facebook.com/benefitedfeaturefilm

Support for our current project will see that commitment to a gender balance in film-making continued.

 

Risks & Challenges

Our production team have demonstrated experience making films with nothing but a catering budget, by leveraging Director Clare McCanns’ extensive history in costume and set design and the generous nature of our team members. We have assembled a fantastic team of highly trained, experienced and enthusiastic professionals for this medieval short, who are all fully committed to seeing it come to life.

What we need now are the funds to hire top-of-line equipment to allow us to craft a screen experience any Game of Thrones and Hobbit fan would be delighted to watch.

 

Other Ways You Can Help

A financial investment - no matter how small - will help deliver our ambitions for this project, and create an amazing addition to the medieval film genre. We do understand that not everyone is in a position to help us with a financial investment. If this is the case, please share this fundraising campaigns a few times with your friends and networks, to help us connect with a wider audience of potential investors.

story:
Short Summary

Remnants of a drowned town resurface mirroring the murkiness of the relationship between Aoife, a local photographer, and her lover, Saoirse, as they camp by Blessington Lake in Co.Wicklow, Ireland. 

Our project, Poulaphouca, is a short film about a broken love story. Inspired by the town of Ballinahown submerged by the Poulaphouca reservoir in scenic Co. Wicklow, Ireland.

This project is a graduate film project collaboration between DOP Daniel Bolaños Meade and Writer/Director Ellen Bytyqi for an international MA course held at IADT. With your help, we can achieve their cinematic vision. 

The Cast

We are so happy to have such a talented cast for our leading roles.


Johanna O’Brien has many years of experience in theatre and film and has trained at the Lir Academy in Dublin, Ireland. Known for her roles on the TV series Krypton (2018) and feature film Rosie (2018). Johanna has just wrapped on the TV series Foundations which airs later this year on Apple TV.

 

Tania Notaro, actor and screenwriter is known for her TV roles in AMC’s Into The Badlands, CBS’ Evidence of Evil, Feature films Cardboard Gangsters (2017) and Red Room (2017), and many short films. Tania is a graduate of Bow Street Actors Academy, The Gaiety School of Acting, and Momentum Studios where she studied the Meisner approach.

 

What We Need & What You Get

We will require €6,000 funding to achieve our perfect vision for this project. This money will go towards:

- feeding our hardworking crew
- transport for crew and equipment
- art department costs like costume, makeup, and set design. 
- paying our lovely cast members
- hiring equipment like generators and portaloos for our exterior shoot
- COVID-19 safety supplies
- distribution costs to enter the finished film into festivals

Perks

With your contribution, you might be able to qualify for one of our great perks such as:

1. An A4 collage print of Poulaphouca by artist Poot Mendes as seen on our Instagram page. 
2. Special funders pack which includes a ticket to a private screening and a behind-the-scenes pamphlet as a token of our appreciation. 
3. Associate Producer credit 

Any contribution over €30 will receive a Special Thanks in our credits!

The Impact

On top of being a graduate project for DOP Daniel Bolaños Meade, the film and story is an important representation of Irish women, members of the LGBTQ community, for immigrants and their families working in Ireland as well as capturing a small part of Irish history, taking inspiration from Poulaphouca and its rich past.

The Team

Director and writer Ellen Bytyqi's previous short film 69 and Dead premiered at the Galway Film Fleadh. Poulaphouca is a serious passion project for her, having grown up in Blessington hearing countless stories about the village of Ballinahown which lies beneath the lake. Ellen is currently undertaking her MA in Screenwriting at IADT.

DOP Daniel Bolaños Meade has worked for years in the Mexican film industry and has previously crowdfunded the cubism-inspired project Revoltoso. Daniel is currently undertaking his MA in Cinematography at IADT and recently was awarded a prize at the RTS ROI Student Awards for his collaborative work with Karin Pritzel for the documentary Fatherly. 

Producer Joanne Heffernan completed her MA in Creative Production and Screen Finance from IADT last year, launching Fly Away Home Productions. With a background in script supervision, administration, and screenwriting, Joanne brings the perfect blend of organizational skills and creative energy to the table and has worked with creative companies in both Ireland and New Zealand. As a writer, Joanne has previously received Screen Ireland funding for her short MAYA. 

Fiona Hamilton and Mary Burke are co-editors on Poulaphouca. As a team, they will aim to work together to create a piece of art through editing. With over 4 years of experience with Boulder Media, Fiona and Mary will bring excellent knowledge of how pacing, music, and sound effects add to a scene and take care in allowing her editing to match the flow of the dialogue.

Emmanuel Mendoza Zárraga is a music composer since 2008, as well as an independent film post-producer since 2016. He studied Composition and Contemporary Music Production. He lives in Mexico City and specializes in Music Scoring for Film, Theme Music For Film, Sound Design & Music Production. 

We are excited to collaborate with talented local singer-songwriting Bat Kinane who created a poignant song about the village of Ballinahown which will feature in our short film as well in our sizzle reel seen above.

Sarah Hamilton, writer and MA graduate in Creative Writing at University College Dublin. Currently, she works as a freelance journalist and copywriter. Sarah is the script editor on this project.

Lia Caira, our Assistant Director, has worked in theatre, film, and TV in both Dublin and Toronto, CA and is also a writer and director from Dublin, Ireland. She graduated with academic awards from ICFE, BCFE, and DCU. In Toronto, her stage play The Night Tithe was selected and performed for the Scripted Toronto Theatre Festival 2019. It was also selected as a finalist for Best Screenplay in the Waterford Film Festival 2020. Lia has also directed the pilot for a new web-series titled Soul Sisters written by Khadar Omar.

Risks & Challenges

 With IADT supplying a trained COVID Officer, we will ensure there will be continuous assessments of the risks involved with shooting; with consistent reminders to crew to keep their distance where possible especially before and after breaks as well as during movements between setups/locations. 

Other Ways You Can Help

If this project excites you please share with your friends! You can also follow our journey on Instagram

_________________________________________

All imagery sourced from:

www.pixabay.com
www.pexels.com
www.youtube.com/itsmyireland

Daniel is currently undertaking his MA in Cinematography at IADT and recently was awarded a prize at the RTS ROI Student Awards for his collaborative work with Karin Pritzel for the documentary Fatherly. 
Producer Joanne Heffernan completed her MA in Creative Production and Screen Finance from IADT last year, launching Fly Away Home Productions. With a background in script supervision, administration, and screenwriting, Joanne brings the perfect blend of organizational skills and creative energy to the table and has worked with creative companies in both Ireland and New Zealand. As a writer, Joanne has previously received Screen Ireland funding for her short MAYA. 
Fiona Hamilton and Mary Burke are co-editors on Poulaphouca. As a team, they will aim to work together to create a piece of art through editing. With over 4 years of experience with Boulder Media, Fiona and Mary will bring excellent knowledge of how pacing, music, and sound effects add to a scene and take care in allowing her editing to match the flow of the dialogue.
Emmanuel Mendoza Zárraga is a music composer since 2008, as well as an independent film post-producer since 2016. He studied Composition and Contemporary Music Production. He lives in Mexico City and specializes in Music Scoring for Film, Theme Music For Film, Sound Design & Music Production. 
We are excited to collaborate with talented local singer-songwriting Bat Kinane who created a poignant song about the village of Ballinahown which will feature in our short film as well in our sizzle reel seen above.
Sarah Hamilton, writer and MA graduate in Creative Writing at University College Dublin. Currently, she works as a freelance journalist and copywriter. Sarah is the script editor on this project.
Lia Caira, our Assistant Director, has worked in theatre, film, and TV in both Dublin and Toronto, CA and is also a writer and director from Dublin, Ireland. She graduated with academic awards from ICFE, BCFE, and DCU. In Toronto, her stage play The Night Tithe was selected and performed for the Scripted Toronto Theatre Festival 2019. It was also selected as a finalist for Best Screenplay in the Waterford Film Festival 2020. Lia has also directed the pilot for a new web-series titled Soul Sisters written by Khadar Omar.


Risks & Challenges
 With IADT supplying a trained COVID Officer, we will ensure there will be continuous assessments of the risks involved with shooting; with consistent reminders to crew to keep their distance where possible especially before and after breaks as well as during movements between setups/locations. 

Other Ways You Can Help
If this project excites you please share with your friends! You can also follow our journey on Instagram
_________________________________________
All imagery sourced from: 
www.pixabay.comwww.pexels.comwww.youtube.com/itsmyireland

story:
What's Our Story?

Evelyn reenters Brian's life with honest intentions to reconnect, but inadvertently ends up unearthing the past.

Life is marked by ambivalence and uncertainty. This film attempts to explore the denial of pain and the turbid relationship between the past and the present that distills itself in the afterlife of a broken relationship.

Expected to shoot in late February, 2021.

Our Team

Some of Our References

Our Previous Work

The majority of this team has a very collaborative history.
